revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2016}} In March 1984, a serious radiation accident occurred in Morocco, where eight people died from [[Pulmonary hemorrhage|pulmonary hemorrhaging]] caused by overexposure to [[radiation]] from a lost [[iridium-192]] source.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Radiological accidents: A historical review of sealed sources accidents|last = Lushbaugh|first = C|last2 = Ricks|first2 = R|last3 = Fry|first3 = S|publisher = International Atomic Energy Agency|year = 1988|isbn =|location =|pages =}}</ref> Other individuals also received significant overdoses of radiation that required medical attention. Three people were sent to the [[Curie Institute (Paris)|Curie Institute]] in Paris for treatment of radiation poisoning.
The [[Radiographic equipment|source]] was used to [[Industrial radiography|radiograph]] welds and became separated from its [[Radiation protection|shielded]] container. As the source itself had no markings indicating it was radioactive, a worker took it home, where it stayed for some weeks, exposing the family to radiation. The laborer, his family, and some relatives were the eight deaths caused by the accident.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/gen-comm/info-notices/1985/in85057.html|title = Information Notice No. 85-57: Lost Iridium-192 Source Resulting in the Death of Eight Persons in Morocco|last = Metzger|first = J.|date = 1985|publisher = United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission|access-date = March 31, 2016}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Nuclear and radiation accidents]] * [[Goiânia accident]] * [[Radiotherapy accident in Costa Rica]] * [[Radiotherapy accident in Zaragoza]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web|title= Information Notice No. 85-57: Lost Iridium-192 Source Resulting in the Death of Eight Persons in Morocco|work= [[United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission]]|url= https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/gen-comm/info-notices/1985/in85057.html}} * [http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/nuclear/radevents/1984MOR1.html Description of the incident in Johnston's Archive]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Radiation accident in Morocco}} [[Category:Man-made disasters in Morocco]] [[Category:1984 industrial disasters]] [[Category:Radiation accidents and incidents|Morocco]] [[Category:1984 in Morocco]] [[Category:March 1984 events]]
{{Environmental-disaster-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About|practical application in the solar energy industry|more comprehensive theoretical treatment|Air mass (astronomy)}}
The '''''air mass coefficient''''' defines the direct optical path length through the [[Earth's atmosphere]], expressed as a ratio relative to the path length vertically upwards, i.e. at the [[zenith]]. The air mass coefficient can be used to help characterize the solar spectrum after [[solar radiation]] has traveled through the atmosphere. The air mass coefficient is commonly used to characterize the performance of [[solar cell]]s under standardized conditions, and is often referred to using the syntax "AM" followed by a number. "AM1.5" is almost universal when characterizing terrestrial power-generating panels.
==Description== [[File:EffectiveTemperature 300dpi e.png|thumb|The [[effective temperature]], or [[black body]] temperature, of the Sun (5777 K) is the temperature a black body of the same size must have to yield the same total emissive power.]] [[File:Solar Spectrum.png|thumb|Solar irradiance spectrum above atmosphere and at surface]]
Solar radiation closely matches a [[black body]] radiator at about 5,800 K.<ref name="NASA5777K">or more precisely 5,777 K as reported in [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Display=Facts&Object=Sun NASA Solar System Exploration - Sun: Facts & Figures] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703111716/http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Sun&Display=Facts |date=2015-07-03 }} retrieved 27 April 2011 "Effective Temperature ... 5777 K"</ref> As it passes through the atmosphere, sunlight is attenuated by [[scattering]] and [[absorption (electromagnetic radiation)|absorption]]; the more atmosphere through which it passes, the greater the [[attenuation]].
As the sunlight travels through the atmosphere, chemicals interact with the sunlight and absorb certain wavelengths changing the amount of short-wavelength light reaching the Earth's surface. A more active component of this process is water vapor, which results in a wide variety of absorption bands at many wavelengths, while molecular nitrogen, oxygen and carbon dioxide add to this process. By the time it reaches the Earth's surface, the spectrum is strongly confined between the far infrared and near ultraviolet.
Atmospheric scattering plays a role in removing higher frequencies from direct sunlight and scattering it about the sky.<ref>See also the article [[Diffuse sky radiation]].</ref> This is why the sky appears blue and the sun yellow — more of the higher-frequency blue light arrives at the observer via indirect scattered paths; and less blue light follows the direct path, giving the sun a yellow tinge.<ref>Yellow is the [[color negative]] of blue — yellow is the aggregate color of what remains after scattering removes some blue from the "white" light from the sun.</ref> The greater the distance in the atmosphere through which the sunlight travels, the greater this effect, which is why the sun looks orange or red at dawn and sundown when the sunlight is travelling very obliquely through the atmosphere — progressively more of the blues and greens are removed from the direct rays, giving an orange or red appearance to the sun; and the sky appears pink — because the blues and greens are scattered over such long paths that they are highly attenuated before arriving at the observer, resulting in characteristic pink skies at dawn and sunset.
==Definition== For a path length <math>L</math> through the atmosphere, and solar radiation incident at angle <math>z</math> relative to the normal to the Earth's surface, the air mass coefficient is:<ref>{{cite book | title = The Physics of Solar Cells | author = Peter Würfel | publisher = Weinheim: Wiley-VCH | date = 2005 }} {{ISBN|3-527-40857-6}}.</ref>
{{NumBlk|:|<math>AM = \frac{L}{L_\mathrm o} \approx \frac{1}{\cos\, z} \,</math>|{{EquationRef|A.1}}}} where <math>L_\mathrm o</math> is the zenith path length (i.e. normal to the Earth's surface) at [[sea level]] and <math>z</math> is the zenith angle in degrees.
The air mass number is thus dependent on the Sun's elevation path through the sky and therefore varies with time of day and with the passing seasons of the year, and with the latitude of the observer.
==Accuracy near the horizon== [[File:Airmass geometry.png|thumb|Atmospheric effects on optical transmission can be modelled as if the atmosphere is concentrated in approximately the lower 9 km.]] The above approximation overlooks the curvature of the Earth, and is reasonably accurate for values of <math>z</math> up to around 75°. A number of refinements have been proposed to more accurately model the path thickness towards the horizon, such as that proposed by Kasten and Young (1989):<ref>Kasten, F. and Young, A. T. (1989). [http://www.opticsinfobase.org/abstract.cfm?uri=ao-28-22-4735 Revised optical air mass tables and approximation formula]. ''Applied Optics'' 28:4735–4738.</ref> {{NumBlk|:|<math>AM = \frac{1} { \cos\, z + 0.50572 \,(96.07995 - z)^{-1.6364}} \,</math>|{{EquationRef|A.2}}}} A more comprehensive list of such models is provided in the main article [[Airmass]], for various atmospheric models and experimental data sets. At sea level the air mass towards the horizon (<math>z</math> = 90°) is approximately 38.<ref name="AM38">The main article [[Airmass]] reports values in the range 36 to 40 for different atmospheric models</ref>
Modelling the atmosphere as a simple spherical shell provides a reasonable approximation:<ref>Schoenberg, E. (1929). Theoretische Photometrie, g) Über die Extinktion des Lichtes in der Erdatmosphäre. In ''Handbuch der Astrophysik''. Band II, erste Hälfte. Berlin: Springer.</ref> {{NumBlk|:|<math>AM = \sqrt { ( r \cos z )^2 + 2 r + 1 } \; - \; r \cos z \,</math>|{{EquationRef|A.3}}}} where the radius of the Earth <math>R_\mathrm E</math> = 6371 km, the effective height of the atmosphere <math>y_\mathrm{atm}</math> ≈ 9 km, and their ratio <math>r = R_\mathrm E / y_\mathrm{atm}</math> ≈ 708.
These models are compared in the table below: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Estimates of airmass coefficient at sea level |- ! <math>z</math> ! Flat Earth ! Kasten & Young ! Spherical shell |- ! degree ! ({{EquationNote|A.1}}) ! ({{EquationNote|A.2}}) ! ({{EquationNote|A.3}}) |- | 0° | 1.0 | 1.0 | 1.0 |- | 60° | 2.0 | 2.0 | 2.0 |- | 70° | 2.9 | 2.9 | 2.9 |- | 75° | 3.9 | 3.8 | 3.8 |- | 80° | 5.8 | 5.6 | 5.6 |- | 85° | 11.5 | 10.3 | 10.6 |- | 88° | 28.7 | 19.4 | 20.3 |- | 90° | <math>\infty</math> | 37.9 | 37.6 |}
This implies that for these purposes the atmosphere can be considered to be effectively concentrated into around the bottom 9 km,<ref>The main article [[Airmass]] reports values in the range 8 to 10 km for different atmospheric models</ref> i.e. essentially all the atmospheric effects are due to the atmospheric mass in the lower half of the [[Troposphere]]. This is a useful and simple model when considering the atmospheric effects on solar intensity.
==Cases==
*'''AM0''' The spectrum outside the atmosphere, approximated by the 5,800 K black body, is referred to as "AM0", meaning "zero atmospheres". Solar cells used for space power applications, like those on [[communications satellite]]s are generally characterized using AM0.
*'''AM1''' The spectrum after travelling through the atmosphere to sea level with the sun directly overhead is referred to, by definition, as "AM1". This means "one atmosphere". AM1 (<math>z</math>=0°) to AM1.1 (<math>z</math>=25°) is a useful range for estimating performance of solar cells in [[equatorial climate|equatorial]] and [[tropical]] regions.
*'''AM1.5''' Solar panels do not generally operate under exactly one atmosphere's thickness: if the sun is at an angle to the Earth's surface the effective thickness will be greater. Many of the world's major population centres, and hence solar installations and industry, across Europe, China, Japan, the United States of America and elsewhere (including northern India, southern Africa and Australia) lie in [[temperate]] latitudes. An AM number representing the spectrum at mid-latitudes is therefore much more common.
"AM1.5", 1.5 atmosphere thickness, corresponds to a solar zenith angle of <math>z</math>=48.2°. While the summertime AM number for mid-latitudes during the middle parts of the day is less than 1.5, higher figures apply in the morning and evening and at other times of the year. Therefore, AM1.5 is useful to represent the overall yearly average for mid-latitudes. The specific value of 1.5 has been selected in the 1970s for standardization purposes, based on an analysis of solar irradiance data in the conterminous United States.<ref name=Gueymard2002> {{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0038-092X(03)00005-7 | title = Proposed reference irradiance spectra for solar energy systems testing | date = 2002 | last1 = Gueymard | first1 = C. | last2 = Myers | first2 = D. | last3 = Emery | first3 = K. | journal = Solar Energy | volume = 73 | issue = 6 | pages = 443–467 | bibcode = 2002SoEn...73..443G }} </ref> Since then, the solar industry has been using AM1.5 for all standardized testing or rating of terrestrial solar cells or modules, including those used in concentrating systems. The latest AM1.5 standards pertaining to photovoltaic applications are the ASTM G-173<ref name="NREL">[http://rredc.nrel.gov/solar/spectra/am1.5/ Reference Solar Spectral Irradiance: Air Mass 1.5] NREL retrieved 1 May 2011</ref><ref name="G173">[http://rredc.nrel.gov/solar/spectra/am1.5/ASTMG173/ASTMG173.html Reference Solar Spectral Irradiance: ASTM G-173] ASTM retrieved 1 May 2011</ref> and IEC 60904, all derived from simulations obtained with the [[SMARTS (The Simple Model of the Atmospheric Radiative Transfer of Sunshine)|SMARTS]] code
*'''AM2~3''' AM2 (<math>z</math>=60°) to AM3 (<math>z</math>=70°) is a useful range for estimating the overall average performance of solar cells installed at high latitudes such as in northern Europe. Similarly AM2 to AM3 is useful to estimate wintertime performance in temperate latitudes, e.g. airmass coefficient is greater than 2 at all hours of the day in winter at latitudes as low as 37°.
*'''AM38''' AM38 is generally regarded as being the airmass in the horizontal direction (<math>z</math>=90°) at sea level.<ref name="AM38" /> However, in practice there is a high degree of variability in the solar intensity received at angles close to the horizon as described in the next section [[#Solar intensity|Solar intensity]].
*'''At higher altitudes''' The ''relative'' air mass is only a function of the sun's zenith angle, and therefore does not change with local elevation. Conversely, the ''absolute'' air mass, equal to the relative air mass multiplied by the local atmospheric pressure and divided by the standard (sea-level) pressure, decreases with elevation above sea level. For solar panels installed at high altitudes, e.g. in an [[Altiplano]] region, it is possible to use a lower absolute AM numbers than for the corresponding latitude at sea level: AM numbers less than 1 towards the equator, and correspondingly lower numbers than listed above for other latitudes. However, this approach is approximate and not recommended. It is best to simulate the actual spectrum based on the relative air mass (e.g., 1.5) and the ''actual'' atmospheric conditions for the specific elevation of the site under scrutiny.
==Solar intensity== Solar intensity at the collector reduces with increasing airmass coefficient, but due to the complex and variable atmospheric factors involved, not in a simple or linear fashion. For example, almost all high energy radiation is removed in the upper atmosphere (between AM0 and AM1) and so AM2 is not twice as bad as AM1. Furthermore, there is great variability in many of the factors contributing to atmospheric attenuation,<ref name="Earthscan">''Planning and installing photovoltaic systems: a guide for installers, architects and engineers'', 2nd Ed. (2008), Table 1.1, [http://www.earthscan.co.uk Earthscan] with the International Institute for Environment and Development, Deutsche Gesellshaft für Sonnenenergie. {{ISBN|1-84407-442-0}}.</ref> such as water vapor, aerosols, [[photochemical smog]] and the effects of [[temperature inversion]]s. Depending on level of pollution in the air, overall attenuation can change by up to ±70% towards the horizon, greatly affecting performance particularly towards the horizon where effects of the lower layers of atmosphere are amplified manyfold.
One approximate model for solar intensity versus airmass is given by:<ref name="PVCDROM">[http://www.pveducation.org/pvcdrom/2-properties-sunlight/air-mass PVCDROM] retrieved 1 May 2011, Stuart Bowden and Christiana Honsberg, [http://pv.asu.edu/ Solar Power Labs, Arizona State University]</ref><ref name="Meinel">Meinel, A. B. and Meinel, M. P. (1976). ''Applied Solar Energy'' Addison Wesley Publishing Co.</ref> {{NumBlk|:|<math>I = 1.1 \times I_\mathrm{o} \times 0.7^{(AM^{0.678})} \,</math>|{{EquationRef|I.1}}}} where solar intensity external to the Earth's atmosphere <math>I_\mathrm o</math> = 1.353 kW/m<sup>2</sup>, and the factor of 1.1 is derived assuming that the diffuse component is 10% of the direct component.<ref name="PVCDROM"/>
This formula fits comfortably within the mid-range of the expected pollution-based variability:
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Solar intensity vs. zenith angle <math>z</math> and airmass coefficient AM |- ! <math>z</math> ! AM ! range due to pollution<ref name="Earthscan" /> ! formula ({{EquationNote|I.1}}) ! ASTM G-173<ref name="G173" /> |- ! degree ! ! W/m<sup>2</sup> ! W/m<sup>2</sup> ! W/m<sup>2</sup> |- | - | 0 | 1367<ref>The ''Earthscan'' reference uses 1367 W/m<sup>2</sup> as the solar intensity external to the atmosphere.</ref> | 1353 | 1347.9<ref>The ASTM G-173 standard measures solar intensity over the band 280 to 4000 [[Nanometre|nm]].</ref> |- | 0° | 1 | 840 .. 1130 = 990 ± 15% | 1040 |- | 23° | 1.09 | <small>800 .. 1110 = 960 ± 16%</small><ref name="interpolation">Interpolated from data in the ''Earthscan'' reference using suitable [[Least squares|Least squares estimate]] variants of equation {{EquationNote|I.1}}:
:for polluted air: {{NumBlk|::|<math>I = 1.1 \times I_\mathrm{o} \times 0.56^{(AM^{0.715})} \,</math>|{{EquationRef|I.3}}}}
:for clean air: {{NumBlk|::|<math>I = 1.1 \times I_\mathrm{o} \times 0.76^{(AM^{0.618})} \,</math>|{{EquationRef|I.4}}}} </ref> | 1020 |- | 30° | 1.15 | 780 .. 1100 = 940 ± 17% | 1010 |- | 45° | 1.41 | <small>710 .. 1060 = 880 ± 20%</small><ref name="interpolation" /> | 950 |- | bgcolor="aquamarine" | 48.2° | bgcolor="aquamarine" | 1.5 | bgcolor="aquamarine" | <small>680 .. 1050 = 870 ± 21%</small><ref name="interpolation" /> | bgcolor="aquamarine" | 930 | bgcolor="aquamarine" | 1000.4<ref>The ASTM G-173 standard measures solar intensity under "rural aerosol loading" i.e. clean air conditions - thus the standard value fits closely to the maximum of the expected range.</ref> |- | 60° | 2 | 560 .. 970 = 770 ± 27% | 840 |- | 70° | 2.9 | <small>430 .. 880 = 650 ± 34%</small><ref name="interpolation" /> | 710 |- | 75° | 3.8 | <small>330 .. 800 = 560 ± 41%</small><ref name="interpolation" /> | 620 |- | 80° | 5.6 | 200 .. 660 = 430 ± 53% | 470 |- | 85° | 10 | 85 .. 480 = 280 ± 70% | 270 |- | 90° | 38 | | 20 |}
This illustrates that significant power is available at only a few degrees above the horizon. For example, when the sun is more than about 60° above the horizon (<math>z</math> <30°) the solar intensity is about 1000 W/m<sup>2</sup> (from equation {{EquationNote|I.1}} as shown in the above table), whereas when the sun is only 15° above the horizon (<math>z</math> =75°) the solar intensity is still about 600 W/m<sup>2</sup> or 60% of its maximum level; and at only 5° above the horizon still 27% of the maximum.
===At higher altitudes===
One approximate model for intensity increase with altitude and accurate to a few kilometres above sea level is given by:<ref name="PVCDROM" /><ref>Laue, E. G. (1970), [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B6V50-497T7KC-T/2/c932c2f01c2de3c36c0f461c991f791a The measurement of solar spectral irradiance at different terrestrial elevations], ''Solar Energy'', vol. 13, no. 1, pp. 43-50, IN1-IN4, 51-57, 1970.</ref> {{NumBlk|:|<math>I = 1.1 \times I_\mathrm{o} \times [ (1 - h/7.1) 0.7^{(AM)^{0.678})} + h/7.1 ] \,</math>|{{EquationRef|I.2}}}} where <math>h</math> is the solar collector's height above sea level in km and <math>AM</math> is the airmass (from {{EquationNote|A.2}}) ''as if'' the collector was installed at sea level.
Alternatively, given the significant practical variabilities involved, the [[Airmass#Homogeneous spherical atmosphere with elevated observer|homogeneous spherical model]] could be applied to estimate AM, using: {{NumBlk|:|<math>AM = \sqrt { ( r+c )^2 \cos^2 z + ( 2r+1+c ) ( 1-c ) } \; - \; ( r+c ) \cos z \,</math>|{{EquationRef|A.4}}}} where the normalized heights of the atmosphere and of the collector are respectively <math>r = R_\mathrm E / y_\mathrm{atm}</math> ≈ 708 (as above) and <math>c = h / y_\mathrm{atm}</math> .
And then the above table or the appropriate equation ({{EquationNote|I.1}} or {{EquationNote|I.3}} or {{EquationNote|I.4}} for average, polluted or clean air respectively) can be used to estimate intensity from AM in the normal way.
These approximations at {{EquationNote|I.2}} and {{EquationNote|A.4}} are suitable for use only to altitudes of a few kilometres above sea level, implying as they do reduction to AM0 performance levels at only around 6 and 9 km respectively. By contrast much of the attenuation of the high energy components occurs in the ozone layer - at higher altitudes around 30 km.<ref>R.L.F. Boyd (Ed.) (1992). ''Astronomical photometry: a guide'', section 6.4. Kluwer Academic Publishers. {{ISBN|0-7923-1653-3}}.</ref> Hence these approximations are suitable only for estimating the performance of ground-based collectors.
==Solar cell efficiency==
{{Main|Solar cell efficiency}}
Silicon solar cells are not very sensitive to the portions of the spectrum lost in the atmosphere. The resulting spectrum at the Earth's surface more closely matches the [[bandgap]] of [[silicon]] so silicon solar cells are more efficient at AM1 than AM0. This apparently counter-intuitive result arises simply because silicon cells can't make much use of the high energy radiation which the atmosphere filters out. As illustrated below, even though the ''efficiency'' is lower at AM0 the ''total output power'' ('''P<sub>out</sub>''') for a typical solar cell is still highest at AM0. Conversely, the shape of the spectrum does not significantly change with further increases in atmospheric thickness, and hence cell efficiency does not greatly change for AM numbers above 1.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Output power vs. airmass coefficient |- ! AM ! Solar intensity ! Output power ! Efficiency |- ! ! P<sub>in</sub> W/m<sup>2</sup> ! P<sub>out</sub> W/m<sup>2</sup> ! P<sub>out</sub> / P<sub>in</sub> |- | 0 | 1350 | 160 | 12% |- | 1 | 1000 | 150 | 15% |- | 2 | 800 | 120 | 15% |}
This illustrates the more general point that given that solar energy is "free", and where available space is not a limitation, other factors such as total '''P<sub>out</sub>''' and '''P<sub>out</sub>/$''' are often more important considerations than efficiency ('''P<sub>out</sub>/P<sub>in</sub>''').
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Air mass (astronomy)]] * [[Diffuse sky radiation]] * [[Earth's atmosphere]] * [[Insolation]] * [[Mie scattering]] * [[Photovoltaics]] * [[Rayleigh scattering]] * [[Solar cell]] * [[Solar cell efficiency]] * [[Solar energy]] * [[Solar power]] * [[Solar radiation]] * [[Solar tracker]] * [[Sun]] * [[Sun chart]] * [[Sun path]] {{div col end}}
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|appetite}} {{Infobox mineral | name = Apatite group | category = [[Phosphate mineral]] | boxwidth = | image = Apatite Canada.jpg | caption = | formula = Ca5(PO4)3(F,Cl,OH) | molweight = | strunz = 8.BN.05 | color = [[transparency (optics)|Transparent]] to translucent, usually green, less often colorless, yellow, blue to violet, pink, brown.[[Gemological Institute of America]], ''GIA Gem Reference Guide'' 1995, {{ISBN|0-87311-019-6}} | habit = Tabular, prismatic crystals, massive, compact or granular | system = [[Hexagonal (crystal system)|Hexagonal]] | class = Dipyramidal (6/m)
(same [[H-M symbol]])[http://webmineral.com/data/Apatite.shtml Apatite]. Webmineral | twinning = | cleavage = [0001] indistinct, [1010] indistinct | fracture = Conchoidal to uneven | mohs = 5 (defining mineral) | luster = Vitreous to subresinous | polish = Vitreous | refractive = 1.634–1.638 (+0.012, −0.006) | opticalprop = Double refractive, uniaxial negative | birefringence = 0.002–0.008 | dispersion = 0.013 | pleochroism = ''Blue stones'' – strong, blue and yellow to colorless. Other colors are weak to very weak. | fluorescence= ''Yellow stones'' – purplish-pink, which is stronger in long wave; ''blue stones'' – blue to light-blue in both long and short wave; ''green stones'' – greenish-yellow, which is stronger in long wave; ''violet stones'' – greenish-yellow in long wave, light-purple in short wave. | absorption = | streak = White | gravity = 3.16–3.22 | density = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = Transparent to translucent | other = }} '''Apatite''' is a group of [[phosphate minerals]], usually referring to [[hydroxylapatite]], [[fluorapatite]] and [[chlorapatite]], with high concentrations of [[Hydroxide|OH]]−, [[Fluoride|F]]− and [[Chloride|Cl]]− [[ion]]s, respectively, in the [[crystal]]. The formula of the admixture of the three most common [[Endmember (mineralogy)|endmembers]] is written as [[Calcium|Ca]]10([[Phosphate|PO4]])6(OH,F,Cl)2, and the crystal unit cell formulae of the individual [[mineral]]s are written as Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, Ca10(PO4)6F2 and Ca10(PO4)6Cl2. The mineral was named apatite by the German [[geologist]] [[Abraham Gottlob Werner]] in 1786,According to Werner himself — (Werner, 1788), p. 85 — the name "apatite" first appeared in print in: * Gerhard, C.A., ''Grundriss des Mineral-systems'' [Outline of the system of minerals] (Berlin, (Germany): Christian Friedrich Himburg, 1786), [https://books.google.com/books?id=DRI-AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA281#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 281.] From p. 281: ''"Von einigen noch nicht genau bestimmten und ganz neu entdeckten Mineralien. Ich rechne hierzu folgende drei Körper: 1. Den Apatit des Herrn Werners. … "''(On some still not precisely determined and quite recently discovered minerals. I count among these the following three substances: 1. the apatite of Mr. Werner. … ) Werner described the mineral in some detail in an article of 1788. * Werner, A.G. (1788) [https://books.google.com/books?id=XyU7AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q&f=false "Geschichte, Karakteristik, und kurze chemische Untersuchung des Apatits"] (History, characteristics, and brief chemical investigation of apatite), ''Bergmännisches Journal'' (Miners' Journal), vol. 1, pp. 76–96. [https://books.google.com/books?id=XyU7AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA84#v=onepage&q&f=false On pp. 84–85], Werner explained that because mineralogists had repeatedly misclassified it (e.g., as [[Beryl#Aquamarine_and_maxixe|aquamarine]]), he gave apatite the name of "deceiver": ''"Ich wies hierauf diesem Foßile, als einer eigenen Gattung, sogleich eine Stelle in dem Kalkgeschlechte an; und ertheilte ihm, — weil es bisher alle Mineralogen in seiner Bestimmung irre geführt hatte, — den Namen ''Apatit'', den ich von dem griechischen Worte ''απατάω'' (decipio) bildete, und welcher so viel as ''Trügling'' sagt."'' (I then immediately assigned to this fossil [i.e., material obtained from underground], as a separate type, a place in the lime lineage; and conferred on it — because it had previously led astray all mineralogists in its classification — the name "apatite", which I formed from the Greek word ''απατάω'' [apatao] (I deceive) and which says as much as [the word] "deceiver".) although the specific mineral he had described was reclassified as fluorapatite in 1860 by the German [[mineralogist]] [[Karl Friedrich August Rammelsberg]]. Apatite is often mistaken for other minerals. This tendency is reflected in the mineral's name, which is derived from the Greek word απατείν (apatein), which means ''to deceive'' or ''to be misleading''.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindat.org/min-1572.html |title=Fluorapatite mineral information and data |website=mindat.org |access-date=30 January 2018}} Apatite is one of a few minerals produced and used by biological micro-environmental systems. Apatite is the defining mineral for 5 on the [[Mohs scale of mineral hardness|Mohs scale]]. Hydroxyapatite, also known as hydroxylapatite, is the major component of [[tooth enamel]] and [[bone mineral]]. A relatively rare form of apatite in which most of the OH groups are absent and containing many [[carbonate]] and acid phosphate substitutions is a large component of [[bone]] material. Fluorapatite (or fluoroapatite) is more resistant to acid attack than is hydroxyapatite; in the mid-20th century, it was discovered that communities whose water supply naturally contained fluorine had lower rates of [[dental caries]].{{vcite web |url=http://www.nidcr.nih.gov/OralHealth/Topics/Fluoride/TheStoryofFluoridation.htm |title=The story of fluoridation |publisher=National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research |date=2008-12-20 }} [[Fluoridated water]] allows exchange in the [[tooth|teeth]] of fluoride ions for [[Hydroxyl#Hydroxyl group|hydroxyl groups]] in apatite. Similarly, toothpaste typically contains a source of fluoride [[anions]] (e.g. sodium fluoride, [[sodium monofluorophosphate]]). Too much fluoride results in [[dental fluorosis]] and/or [[skeletal fluorosis]]. [[Fission track dating|Fission tracks]] in apatite are commonly used to determine the thermal histories of [[Orogenic belt|orogenic (mountain) belts]] and of [[Sedimentary rock|sediments]] in [[sedimentary basin]]s{{Cite journal|date=2019|editor-last=Malusà|editor-first=Marco G.|editor2-last=Fitzgerald|editor2-first=Paul G.|title=Fission-Track Thermochronology and its Application to Geology|url=https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-319-89421-8|journal=Springer Textbooks in Earth Sciences, Geography and Environment|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-89421-8|issn=2510-1307}}. [[Helium dating|(U-Th)/He dating]] of apatite is also well established from noble gas diffusion studies{{Cite journal|last=Zeitler|first=P.K.|last2=Herczeg|first2=A.L.|last3=McDougall|first3=I.|last4=Honda|first4=M.|date=1987-10|title=U-Th-He dating of apatite: A potential thermochronometer|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0016-7037(87)90164-5|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=51|issue=10|pages=2865–2868|doi=10.1016/0016-7037(87)90164-5|issn=0016-7037}}{{Cite journal|last=Wolf|first=R.A.|last2=Farley|first2=K.A.|last3=Silver|first3=L.T.|date=1996-11|title=Helium diffusion and low-temperature thermochronometry of apatite|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0016-7037(96)00192-5|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=60|issue=21|pages=4231–4240|doi=10.1016/s0016-7037(96)00192-5|issn=0016-7037}}{{Cite journal|last=Warnock|first=A.C.|last2=Zeitler|first2=P.K.|last3=Wolf|first3=R.A.|last4=Bergman|first4=S.C.|date=1997-12|title=An evaluation of low-temperature apatite U Th/He thermochronometry|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0016-7037(97)00302-5|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=61|issue=24|pages=5371–5377|doi=10.1016/s0016-7037(97)00302-5|issn=0016-7037}}{{Cite journal|last=Farley|first=K. A.|date=2000-02-10|title=Helium diffusion from apatite: General behavior as illustrated by Durango fluorapatite|url=https://doi.org/10.1029/1999JB900348|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth|language=en|volume=105|issue=B2|pages=2903–2914|doi=10.1029/1999jb900348|issn=0148-0227}}{{Cite journal|last=Shuster|first=David L.|last2=Flowers|first2=Rebecca M.|last3=Farley|first3=Kenneth A.|date=2006-09|title=The influence of natural radiation damage on helium diffusion kinetics in apatite|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.epsl.2006.07.028|journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters|volume=249|issue=3-4|pages=148–161|doi=10.1016/j.epsl.2006.07.028|issn=0012-821X}}{{Cite journal|last=Idleman|first=Bruce D.|last2=Zeitler|first2=Peter K.|last3=McDannell|first3=Kalin T.|date=2018-01|title=Characterization of helium release from apatite by continuous ramped heating|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S000925411730640X|journal=Chemical Geology|volume=476|pages=223–232|doi=10.1016/j.chemgeo.2017.11.019|issn=0009-2541}}{{Cite journal|last=McDannell|first=Kalin T.|last2=Zeitler|first2=Peter K.|last3=Janes|first3=Darwin G.|last4=Idleman|first4=Bruce D.|last5=Fayon|first5=Annia K.|date=2018-02|title=Screening apatites for (U-Th)/He thermochronometry via continuous ramped heating: He age components and implications for age dispersion|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0016703717307482|journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|volume=223|pages=90–106|doi=10.1016/j.gca.2017.11.031|issn=0016-7037}} for use in determining thermal histories{{Cite journal|last=House|first=M.A.|last2=Wernicke|first2=B.P.|last3=Farley|first3=K.A.|last4=Dumitru|first4=T.A.|date=1997-10|title=Cenozoic thermal evolution of the central Sierra Nevada, California, from (UTh)/He thermochronometry|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0012-821X(97)81846-8|journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters|volume=151|issue=3-4|pages=167–179|doi=10.1016/s0012-821x(97)81846-8|issn=0012-821X}}{{Cite journal|last=Ehlers|first=Todd A.|last2=Farley|first2=Kenneth A.|date=2003-01|title=Apatite (U–Th)/He thermochronometry: methods and applications to problems in tectonic and surface processes|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0012-821X(02)01069-5|journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters|volume=206|issue=1-2|pages=1–14|doi=10.1016/s0012-821x(02)01069-5|issn=0012-821X}} and other, less typical applications such as paleo-wildfire dating{{Cite journal|last=Reiners|first=P. W.|last2=Thomson|first2=S. N.|last3=McPhillips|first3=D.|last4=Donelick|first4=R. A.|last5=Roering|first5=J. J.|date=2007-10-12|title=Wildfire thermochronology and the fate and transport of apatite in hillslope and fluvial environments|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1029/2007JF000759|journal=Journal of Geophysical Research|language=en|volume=112|issue=F4|doi=10.1029/2007jf000759|issn=0148-0227}}. [[Phosphorite]] is a phosphate-rich [[sedimentary rock]], that contains between 18% and 40% P2O5. The apatite in phosphorite is present as [[cryptocrystalline]] masses referred to as ''collophane''. ==Uses== [[File:Widok na Apatyty z Chibin.JPG|thumb|left|Apatite quarries and processing facilities. View from [[Khibiny Mountains]]]] The primary use of apatite is in the manufacture of [[fertilizer]] – it is a source of phosphorus. It is occasionally used as a gemstone. Green and blue varieties, in finely divided form, are [[pigment]]s with excellent covering power. During digestion of apatite with [[sulfuric acid]] to make [[phosphoric acid]], [[hydrogen fluoride]] is produced as a byproduct from any [[fluorapatite]] content. This byproduct is a minor industrial source of [[hydrofluoric acid]].{{cite journal|last1=Villalba|first1=Gara|last2=Ayres|first2=Robert U.|last3=Schroder|first3=Hans|year=2008|title=Accounting for Fluorine: Production, Use, and Loss|journal=Journal of Industrial Ecology|volume=11|pages=85–101|doi=10.1162/jiec.2007.1075}} Fluoro-chloro apatite forms the basis of the now obsolete Halophosphor [[fluorescent lamp|fluorescent tube]] phosphor system. Dopant elements of manganese and antimony, at less than one mole-percent, in place of the calcium and phosphorus impart the fluorescence, and adjustment of the fluorine-to-chlorine ratio adjusts the shade of white produced. This system has been almost entirely replaced by the Tri-Phosphor system.Henderson and Marsden, "Lamps and Lighting", Edward Arnold Ltd., 1972, {{ISBN|0-7131-3267-1}} In the United States, apatite-derived fertilizers are used to supplement the nutrition of many agricultural crops by providing a valuable source of [[phosphate]]. Apatites are also a proposed host material for storage of [[nuclear waste]], along with other phosphates. ==Gemology== [[File:Apatite taillée.jpg|thumb|left|Faceted blue apatite, Brazil]] Apatite is infrequently used as a [[gemstone]]. [[Transparency (optics)|Transparent]] stones of clean color have been faceted, and [[chatoyant]] specimens have been [[cabochon]]-cut. Chatoyant stones are known as ''cat's-eye apatite'', transparent green stones are known as ''asparagus stone'', and blue stones have been called ''moroxite''.Streeter, Edwin W., [http://www.farlang.com/gemstones/streeter-precious-stones/page_306 Precious Stones and Gems] 6th edition, George Bell and Sons, London, 1898, p306 If crystals of [[rutile]] have grown in the crystal of apatite, in the right light the cut stone displays a cat's-eye effect. Major sources for gem apatite are Brazil, Burma, and Mexico. Other sources include Canada, Czech Republic, Germany, India, Madagascar, Mozambique, Norway, South Africa, Spain, Sri Lanka, and the United States. == Use as an ore mineral == [[Image:Apatite09.jpg|thumb|right|Apatite crystal, Mexico]] Apatite is occasionally found to contain significant amounts of [[rare-earth elements]] and can be used as an [[ore]] for those metals.Salvi S, Williams‐Jones A. 2004. Alkaline granite‐syenite deposits. In Linnen RL, Samson IM, editors. Rare element geochemistry and mineral deposits. St. Catharines (ON): Geological Association of Canada. pp. 315‐341 {{ISBN|1-897095-08-2}} This is preferable to traditional rare-earth ores such as [[monazite]],Haxel G, Hedrick J, Orris J. 2006. [http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2002/fs087-02/fs087-02.pdf Rare earth elements critical resources for high technology]. Reston (VA): United States Geological Survey. USGS Fact Sheet: 087‐02. as apatite is not very radioactive and does not pose an [[environmental hazard]] in [[mine tailings]]. However, apatite often contains [[uranium]] and its equally radioactive [[decay chain|decay-chain]] nuclides.Proctor, Robert N. (2006-12-01) [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/01/opinion/01proctor.html Puffing on Polonium – New York Times]. Nytimes.com. Retrieved on 2011-07-24.[http://www.epa.gov/radiation/sources/tobacco.html#material_cigarette Tobacco Smoke | Radiation Protection | US EPA]. Epa.gov (2006-06-28). Retrieved on 2011-07-24. Apatite is an ore mineral at the [[Hoidas Lake]] rare-earth project.[http://www.gwmg.ca/projects/hoidas-lake Great Western Minerals Group Ltd. | Projects – Hoidas Lake, Saskatchewan]. Gwmg.ca (2010-01-27). Retrieved on 2011-07-24. ==Thermodynamics== The [[Standard enthalpy of formation|standard enthalpies of formation]] in the crystalline state of hydroxyapatite, chlorapatite and a preliminary value for bromapatite, have been determined by reaction-solution [[calorimetry]]. Speculations on the existence of a possible fifth member of the calcium apatites family, iodoapatite, have been drawn from energetic considerations.{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.jct.2005.01.010 |author1=Cruz, F.J.A.L. |author2=Minas da Piedade, M.E. |author3=Calado, J.C.G. |title=Standard molar enthalpies of formation of hydroxy-, chlor-, and bromapatite |journal=J. Chem. Thermodyn. |volume=37 |year=2005 |pages=1061–1070|issue=10}} [[File:Apatite-Khibiny-ivtorov.jpg|thumb|An apatite mine near [[Kirovsk, Murmansk Oblast|Kirovsk]] in the [[Khibiny Mountains]], one of Russia's main sources of phosphate fertilizer]] Structural and [[Thermodynamics|thermodynamic]] properties of crystal hexagonal calcium apatites, Ca10(PO4)6(X)2 (X= OH, F, Cl, Br), have been investigated using an all-atom Born-Huggins-Mayer potentialSee: [http://www.sklogwiki.org/SklogWiki/index.php/Born-Huggins-Meyer_potential Born-Huggins-Mayer potential (SklogWiki)] by a molecular dynamics technique. The accuracy of the model at room temperature and atmospheric pressure was checked against crystal structural data, with maximum deviations of c. 4% for the haloapatites and 8% for hydroxyapatite. High-pressure simulation runs, in the range 0.5-75 kbar, were performed in order to estimate the isothermal compressibility coefficient of those compounds. The deformation of the compressed solids is always elastically anisotropic, with BrAp exhibiting a markedly different behavior from those displayed by HOAp and ClAp. High-pressure p-V data were fitted to the Parsafar-Mason equation of stateParsafar, Gholamabbas and Mason, E.A. (1994) "Universal equation of state for compressed solids," ''Physical Review B Condensed Matter'', '''49''' (5) : 3049–3060. with an accuracy better than 1%.{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/jp054304p |author1=Cruz, F.J.A.L. |author2=Canongia Lopes, J.N. |author3=Calado, J.C.G. |author4=Minas da Piedade, M.E. |title=A Molecular Dynamics Study of the Thermodynamic Properties of Calcium Apatites. 1. Hexagonal Phases |journal=J. Phys. Chem. B |volume=109 |year=2005 |pages=24473–24479|issue=51}} The monoclinic solid phases Ca10(PO4)6(X)2 (X= OH, Cl) and the molten hydroxyapatite compound have also been studied by molecular dynamics.{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/jp055808q |author1=Cruz, F.J.A.L. |author2=Canongia Lopes, J.N. |author3=Calado, J.C.G. |title=Molecular Dynamics Study of the Thermodynamic Properties of Calcium Apatites. 2. Monoclinic Phases |journal=J. Phys. Chem. B |volume=110 |year=2006 |pages=4387–4392|issue=9}}{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.fluid.2005.12.021 |author1=Cruz, F.J.A.L. |author2=Canongia Lopes, J.N. |author3=Calado, J.C.G. |title=Molecular dynamics simulations of molten calcium hydroxyapatite |journal=Fluid Phase Eq. |volume=241 |year=2006 |pages=51–58|issue=1–2}} ==Lunar science== [[Moon rocks]] collected by astronauts during the [[Apollo program]] contain traces of apatite.{{cite journal|author=Smith, J. V.|author2=Anderson, A. T.|author3=Newton, R. C.|author4=Olsen, E. J.|author5=Crewe, A. V.|author6=Isaacson, M. S. |title=Petrologic history of the moon inferred from petrography, mineralogy and petrogenesis of Apollo 11 rocks | bibcode=1970GeCAS...1..897S |journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta |volume=34, Supplement 1 |year=1970 |pages=897–925 | doi = 10.1016/0016-7037(70)90170-5 }} Re-analysis of these samples in 2010 revealed water trapped in the mineral as [[hydroxyl]], leading to estimates of water on the lunar surface at a rate of at least 64 parts per billion – 100 times greater than previous estimates – and as high as 5 parts per million.{{cite journal|doi=10.1073/pnas.1006677107 |author1=McCubbina, Francis M. |author2=Steele, Andrew |author3=Haurib, Erik H. |author4=Nekvasilc, Hanna |author5=Yamashitad, Shigeru |author6=Russell J. Hemleya |title=Nominally hydrous magmatism on the Moon|year=2010|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=107|issue=25|pages=11223–11228|bibcode = 2010PNAS..10711223M |pmid=20547878 |pmc=2895071}} If the minimum amount of mineral-locked water was hypothetically converted to liquid, it would cover the Moon's surface in roughly one meter of water.[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/06/100614-moon-water-hundred-lunar-proceedings-science/ Fazekas, Andrew "Moon Has a Hundred Times More Water Than Thought" National Geographic News (June 14, 2010)]. News.nationalgeographic.com (2010-06-14). Retrieved on 2011-07-24. ==Bio-leaching== The ectomycorrhizal fungi ''[[Suillus granulatus]]'' and ''[[Paxillus involutus]]'' can release elements from apatite.{{cite web|url=http://mic.sgmjournals.org/content/156/3/609.full|title=Metals, minerals and microbes: geomicrobiology and bioremediation|journal=Microbiology|author=Geoffrey Michael Gadd|volume=156|date=March 2010|pages=609–643}} == See also == * [[List of minerals]] * [[Thermal history modelling]] * [[Hexafluorosilicic acid]] * [[Hydroxylapatite]] in [[bone]] ==References== {{commons category|Apatite}} {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Calcium minerals]] [[Category:Phosphate minerals]] [[Category:Gemstones]] [[Category:Piezoelectric materials]] [[Category:Hexagonal minerals]]

revision.comment: /* 2014-2015 */ That's a reference for Jungwirth *leaving* Apple for VW.
revision.text:
{{about|the speculative project from Apple Inc|the 1910 era car|Apple (automobile)}} {{redirect|iCar|the magazine|iCar (magazine)|other uses|ICAR (disambiguation)}}
{{prose|date=April 2016}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}}
The '''Apple electric car project''', codenamed "'''Titan'''",<ref>{{cite news |first = Russell |last = Hotten |url = https://www.bbc.com/news/business-31720645 |publisher = [[BBC News]] |title = Carmakers Face Challenge from Google and Apple |date = March 4, 2015 }}</ref> is an [[electric car]] project allegedly undergoing [[research and development]] by [[Apple Inc.]]<ref name="guardian-2015-08-14">{{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/aug/14/apple-self-driving-car-project-titan-sooner-than-expected |title = Documents Confirm Apple Is Building Self-Driving Car |first1 = Mark |last1 = Harris |date = August 14, 2015 |work = [[The Guardian]] |location = London }}</ref> Apple still has yet to openly discuss any of its self-driving research,<ref name=C/> with around 5,000 employees disclosed on the project as of 2018.<ref name=E/> In May 2018, Apple reportedly partnered with [[Volkswagen]] to produce an autonomous employee shuttle van based on the [[Volkswagen Transporter (T6)|T6 Transporter]] commercial vehicle platform.<ref name="NYT May 2018 VW partnership"/> In August 2018, the [[BBC]] reported that Apple had 66 road-registered driverless cars, with 111 drivers registered to operate those cars.<ref name=H/> The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported on July 25, 2016 that Apple had hired [[Bob Mansfield]] to lead the Titan project.<ref name=W/>
== History == === 2014-2015 === The project was rumored to be approved by Apple CEO [[Tim Cook]] in late 2014 and assigned to Vice President Steve Zadesky, a former [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] engineer as project in-charge.<ref>{{cite news |first = Chuck |last = Jones |date = February 14, 2015 |title = Hitting the Brakes on Apple's Electric Car |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/chuckjones/2015/02/14/hitting-the-brakes-on-apples-electric-car/ |access-date = February 19, 2015 |work = [[Forbes]] }}</ref> For the project, Apple was rumored to have hired Johann Jungwirth, the former-president and chief executive of [[Mercedes-Benz]] Research and Development North America, as well as at least one transmission engineer.<ref>{{cite news |first = Will |last = Flanagan |date = February 13, 2015 |title = A Titanic Announcement: Apple's Making Cars |url = http://chicagoinno.streetwise.co/2015/02/13/apple-cars-everything-you-need-to-know-about-project-titan/ |access-date = February 19, 2015 |work = Chicago Inno }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first = Jordan |last = Kahn |date = February 19, 2015 |title = Revealed: The Experts Apple Hired to Build an Electric Car |url = http://9to5mac.com/2015/02/19/apple-electric-car-team/ |access-date = February 25, 2015 |work = [[9to5Mac]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first = Tim |last = Higgins |agency = Bloomberg News |date = February 17, 2015 |title = Apple Uniquely Positioned to Be Car Company |url = http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/2015/02/16/apple-car-business/23533933/ |access-date = February 19, 2015 |work = [[The Detroit News]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first1 = Edward |last1 = Taylor |first2 = Alexei |last2 = Oreskovic |last-author-amp = yes |date = February 14, 2015 |title = Apple Studies Self-Driving Car, Auto Industry Source Says |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/14/us-apple-autos-idUSKBN0LI0IJ20150214 |access-date = February 19, 2015 |publisher = [[Reuters]] }}</ref>
By February 2015, it was rumored that a substantial number of Apple employees were working on an electric car project,<ref name="wsj-original">{{cite news |title = Apple’s New Electric Car Could Give Tesla a Run for Its Money |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/apples-titan-car-project-to-challenge-tesla-1423868072 |work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] |first1 = Daisuke |last1 = Wakabayashi |first2 = Mike |last2 = Ramsey |last-author-amp = yes |date = February 13, 2015 |accessdate = March 4, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first = Dan |last = Gallagher |date = February 17, 2015 |title = What Apple Is Driving At |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-apple-is-driving-at-heard-on-the-street-1424206410 |access-date = February 19, 2015 |work = The Wall Street Journal }}</ref> with Apple hiring new employees for the project as well.<ref>{{cite news |first = Alex |last = Fitzpatrick |date = February 13, 2015 |title = Apple Reportedly Hiring for Mystery Car Project |url = http://time.com/3709763/apple-car-lab/ |access-date = February 19, 2015 |work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] }}</ref> Reports in February 2015 indicated that the company had been offering incentives to Tesla employees to join Apple.<ref>{{cite web |title = Apple Will Start Developing the Long-Waited iCar |first = Luis Miguel |last = Andujar |date = February 13, 2015 |url = http://www.techamster.com/apple-will-start-developing-long-waited-icar/ |work = TecHampster |access-date = March 4, 2015 }}</ref> In February 2015, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that the product would resemble more of a [[minivan]] than a car,<ref name="wsj-original"/> and ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' said at that time that production could start as soon as 2020.<ref name="tim-higgins-bloomberg">{{cite news |first = Tim |last = Higgins |date = February 20, 2015 |title = Apple Wants to Start Making Cars as Soon as 2020 |url = http://www.smh.com.au/business/apple-wants-to-start-making-cars-as-soon-as-2020-20150220-13k4bj.html |work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date = March 4, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.technact.com/apple-icar-project/|title=Apple iCar project: New hot wheels on the road-Technact.com|date=2018-02-20|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
In February 2015, Apple board member [[Mickey Drexler]] stated that Apple co-founder and CEO [[Steve Jobs]] had plans to design and build a car, and that discussions about the concept surfaced around the time that [[Tesla Motors]] debuted [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|its first car]] in 2008.<ref>{{cite news |first = Sam |last = Colt |date = February 9, 2015 |url = http://www.businessinsider.com/mickey-drexler-steve-jobs-was-gonna-design-an-icar-2015-2 |title = Apple Board Member: 'Steve Jobs Was Gonna Design an iCar' |work = [[Business Insider]] |access-date = March 4, 2015 }}</ref> In November 2015, Former Apple [[iPod]] Senior VP [[Tony Fadell]] confirmed that Steve Jobs was interested in an Apple car back in 2008, shortly after the original iPhone was introduced.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-04/steve-jobs-considered-building-an-apple-car-in-2008 |title = Steve Jobs Considered Building an Apple Car in 2008 |first = Adam |last = Satariano |date = November 4, 2015 |work = Bloomberg.com |accessdate = January 12, 2016 }}</ref> In May 2015, Apple investor [[Carl Icahn]] stated that he believed rumors that Apple would enter the automobile market in 2020, and that logically Apple would view this car as "the ultimate [[mobile device]]".<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-18/here-s-why-carl-icahn-thinks-apple-will-surge-to-240-per-share |title = Here's Why Carl Icahn Thinks Apple Will Surge to $240 per Share |first = Luke |last = Kawa |date = May 18, 2015 |work = Bloomberg.com |accessdate = May 18, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://carlicahn.com/carl-icahn-issues-open-letter-to-tim-cook/ |title = Carl Icahn Issues Open Letter to Tim Cook |first = Carl C. |last = Icahn |date = May 18, 2015 |accessdate = February 9, 2016 }}</ref>
In August 2015, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that Apple were meeting with officials from [[GoMentum Station]],<ref name="guardian-2015-08-14"/> a testing ground for connected and autonomous vehicles at the former [[Concord Naval Weapons Station]] in [[Concord, California]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://gomentumstation.net/vision/ |title = Vision: GoMentum Station |accessdate = August 14, 2015 }}</ref> In September 2015, there were reports that Apple were meeting with self-driving car experts from the [[California Department of Motor Vehicles]].<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/sep/18/apple-meets-california-officials-self-driving-car |title = Apple Meets California Officials to Discuss Self-Driving Car |first = Mark |last = Harris |date = September 18, 2015 |work = The Guardian |location = London }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.techinsider.io/apple-looks-to-get-autonomous-permit-in-california-2015-9 |title = One Big Sign the Apple Self-Driving Car Is Closer than We Thought |first = Cadie |last = Thompson |work = Tech Insider }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2015/09/18/more-evidence-unearthed-that-apple-is-working-on.html |title = More Evidence Unearthed that Apple Is Working on Driverless Car |first = Angela |last = Swartz |date = September 18, 2015 |work = [[San Jose Business Journal]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = https://thenextweb.com/apple/2015/09/19/apples-meeting-with-california-dmv-suggests-a-driverless-car-could-be-on-the-way/ |title = Apple’s Meeting with California DMV Suggests a Driverless Car Could Be on the Way |first = Jackie |last = Dove |work = The Next Web }}</ref> According to ''The Wall Street Journal'' in September 2015, it will be a [[battery electric vehicle]], initially lacking full [[autonomous driving]] capability, with a possible unveiling around 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.nasdaq.com/article/apple-speeds-up-electriccar-effort-sees-2019-shipments-20150921-00713 |title = Apple Speeds Up Electric-Car Effort, Sees 2019 Shipments |first = Daisuke |last = Wakabayashi |date = September 21, 2015 |work = WSJ |accessdate = September 21, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/09/21/report-apples-electric-car-arriving-2019/72571316/ |title = Report: Apple's Electric Car Arriving in 2019 |date = September 21, 2015 |work = USA Today |accessdate = September 22, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.macworld.com/article/2985155/car-tech/report-apples-electric-car-to-hit-the-road-in-2019-but-it-wont-be-driverless.html |title = Report: Apple’s Electric Car to Hit the Road in 2019 but It Won't Be Driverless |first = Oscar |last = Raymundo |date = September 21, 2015 |work = Macworld |accessdate = September 22, 2015 }}</ref>
In October 2015, Tim Cook stated about the car industry that: "It would seem like there will be massive change in that industry, massive change. You may not agree with that. That's what I think..."We'll see what we do in the future. I do think that the industry is at an inflection point for massive change." Cook enumerated ways that the modern descendants of the [[Ford Model T]] would be shaken to the very chassis—the growing importance of software in the car of the future, the rise of autonomous vehicles, and the shift from an [[internal combustion engine]] to electrification.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://recode.net/2015/10/19/apple-ceo-tim-cook-massive-change-is-coming-to-the-auto-industry/ |title=Apple CEO Tim Cook: ‘Massive Change’ Is Coming to Cars |first=Dawn |last=Chmielewski |date= |work=Re/code |accessdate=October 20, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151020225015/http://recode.net/2015/10/19/apple-ceo-tim-cook-massive-change-is-coming-to-the-auto-industry/ |archivedate=October 20, 2015 }}</ref>
In November 2015, various websites reported that suspected Apple front SixtyEight Research had attended an auto body conference in Europe.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/11/09/shadowy-group-linked-to-apples-project-titan-spotted-at-auto-industry-conference |title = Shadowy Group Linked to Apple's 'Project Titan' Spotted at Auto Industry Conference |date = November 9, 2015 |work = [[Appleinsider]] }}</ref> Also in November 2015, after unknown EV startup [[Faraday Future]] announced a $1 billion U.S. factory project,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.businessinsider.com/faraday-future-electric-car-manufacturing-plant-2015-11 |title = A Mysterious Electric-Car Startup Is Building a $1 Billion Factory in California |first = Justin |last = Pritchard |work = Business Insider |date = November 8, 2015 }}</ref> some speculated that it might actually be a front for Apple's secret car project.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/11/06/rumor-claims-new-electric-car-maker-faraday-future-is-front-for-apple |title = Rumor Claims New Electric Car Maker Faraday Future Is Front for Apple |first = Roger |last = Fingas |date = November 6, 2015 |publisher = AppleInsider }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimgorzelany/2015/11/09/is-faraday-apples-automotive-beard/ |title = Is Faraday Apple's Automotive 'Beard?' |first = Jim |last = Gorzelany |date = November 9, 2015 |work = [[Forbes]] }}</ref> In late 2015, Apple contracted [[Torc Robotics]] to retrofit two [[Lexus]] SUVs with sensors in a project known internally as Baja.<ref name="NYT May 2018 VW partnership"/>
=== 2016 ===
In 2016, [[Tesla Motors]] CEO [[Elon Musk]] stated that Apple will probably make a compelling electric car: "It's pretty hard to hide something if you hire over a thousand engineers to do it."<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-35280633 |title = Tesla Chief Elon Musk Says Apple Is Making an Electric Car |author = |date = |publisher = BBC News |accessdate = January 12, 2016 }}</ref> In May 2016, there were reports indicating Apple was interested in electric car [[charging station]]s.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://in.reuters.com/article/apple-charging-idINKCN0YG25R |title = Exclusive: Apple Explores Charging Stations for Electric Vehicles |first1 = Julia |last1 = Love |first2 = Alexandria |last2 = Sage |last-author-amp = yes |date = May 26, 2016 |publisher = Reuters |access-date = May 28, 2016 }}</ref>
The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported on July 25, 2016 that Apple had convinced retired senior hardware engineering executive [[Bob Mansfield]] to return and take over the Titan project.<ref name=W>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/apple-taps-bob-mansfield-to-oversee-car-project-1469458580|title=Apple Taps Bob Mansfield to Oversee Car Project|author=Daisuke Wakabayashi|date=July 25, 2016|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2016/07/25/apple-car-bob-mansfield/|title=WSJ: Apple recruits retired hardware expert Bob Mansfield to lead Apple Car project|author=Zac Hall|date=July 25, 2016|website=[[9 to 5 Mac]]}}</ref> A few days later, on July 29, ''[[Bloomberg Technology]]'' reported that Apple had hired Dan Dodge, the founder and former chief executive officer of [[QNX]], [[BlackBerry Ltd.]]’s automotive software division. According to ''Bloomberg'', Dodge's hiring heralded a shift in emphasis at Apple's Project Titan, in which the company will give first priority to creating software for autonomous vehicles. However, the story said that Apple would continue to develop a vehicle of its own.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-07-28/apple-taps-blackberry-talent-as-car-project-takes-software-turn|title=Apple Hires BlackBerry Talent With Car Project Turning to Self-Driving Software|last=atbwebb|first=Mark Gurman markgurman Alex Webb|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date= July 29, 2016}}</ref> On September 9, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported dozens of layoffs in an effort to reboot,<ref>{{Cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/10/technology/apple-is-said-to-be-rethinking-strategy-on-self-driving-cars.html?_r=0 |title = Apple Is Said to Be Rethinking Strategy on Self-Driving Cars |last = Wakabayashi |first = Daisuke |work= [[The New York Times]] |access-date = October 12, 2016}}</ref> presumably from a team still numbering around 1,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.macobserver.com/analysis/bob-mansfield-reportedly-shaking-apple-car-project-layoffs/|title=Bob Mansfield Reportedly Shaking Up Apple Car Project With Layoffs|author=Bryan Chaffin|date=September 10, 2016|website=The Mac Observer}}</ref>
The following week, reports surfaced that [[Magna International]], a contract vehicle manufacturer, had a small team working at Apple's Sunnyvale lab.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/apple-car-magna-steyr-ceo-donald-walker-2016-9|title=This little-known company could be building Apple’s car|author=Kif Leswing|date=September 15, 2016|website=Business Insider}}</ref>
===2017===
After a period of no new reports, car project news flared up again in mid-April, 2017, as word spread that Apple was permitted to test autonomous vehicles on California roads.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/14/15303338/apple-autonomous-vehicle-testing-permit-california|title=Apple just received a permit to test self-driving cars in California|author=Andrew J. Hawkins|date=April 14, 2017|website=[[The Verge]]}}</ref> In mid-June, [[Tim Cook]] in an interview with ''[[Bloomberg TV]]'' said Apple was "focusing on autonomous systems" but not necessarily leading to an actual Apple car product, leaving speculation about Apple's role in the convergence of three disruptive "vectors of change": autonomous systems, electric vehicles and ride-sharing services.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://9to5mac.com/2017/06/13/apple-car-tim-cook-confirmation/|title= Tim Cook says self-driving car tech ‘incredibly exciting,’ Apple may or may not make a car|author=Ben Lovejoy|date=June 13, 2017|website=9 to 5 Mac}}</ref>
In mid-August, various sources reported that the car project was focusing on autonomous systems, now expected to test its technology in the real world using a company-operated inter-campus shuttle service between the main Infinite Loop campus in Cupertino and various Silicon Valley offices, including the new Apple Park.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/22/technology/apple-self-driving-car.html|title=Apple Scales Back Its Ambitions for a Self-Driving Car|author=Daisuke Wakabayashi|date=August 22, 2017|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/17/08/22/self-driving-campus-shuttle-to-rise-from-ashes-of-apples-project-titan-report-says|title=Self-driving campus shuttle to rise from ashes of Apple's 'Project Titan,' report says|author=Mikey Campbell|date=August 22, 2017|website=AppleInsider}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/apple-reportedly-scales-back-car-effort-2017-8|title=Apple reportedly scaled back its car ambitions because nobody could agree on what an Apple Car should do|author=Matt Weinberger|date=August 22, 2017|website=Business Insider}}</ref> Then at the end of August, around 17 former Titan team members, braking and suspension engineers with Detroit experience, were hired by autonomous vehicle startup Zoox,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/08/30/apple-self-driving-engineers-head-to-startup-zoox/|title=Apple self-driving engineers head to startup Zoox|author=Seung Lee|date=August 30, 2017|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.macrumors.com/2017/08/30/apple-auto-engineers-join-zoox/|title=Autonomous Vehicle Startup Zoox Snags 17 Former Apple Automotive Engineers|author=Juli Clover|date=August 30, 2017|website=[[MacRumors]]}}</ref> described as "a robotics company pioneering autonomous mobility as-a-service".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/zoox#/entity|title=Zoox {{!}} Crunchbase|website=[[CrunchBase]]}}</ref>
Oct. 2016 reports claimed the Titan project has a 2017 deadline to determine its fate - prove its practicality and viability, set a final direction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://appleinsider.com/articles/16/10/17/apple-car-project-to-choose-new-direction-in-late-2017---report|title='Apple Car' project to choose new direction in late 2017 - report|author=Roger Fingas|date=October 17, 2016|website=[[Apple Insider]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/10/17/apple-executives-to-decide-fate-of-self-driving-car-by-late-2017-report.html|title=Apple executives to decide fate of self-driving car by late 2017: Report|author=Berkeley Lovelace Jr.|date=October 17, 2016|website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref>
In November 2017, Apple employees Yin Zhou and Oncel Tuzel published a paper on VoxelNet, which uses a [[convolutional neural network]] to detect three dimensional objects using [[lidar]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.06396.pdf|title=VoxelNet: End-to-End Learning for Point Cloud Based 3D Object Detection|author1=Yin Zhou|author2=Oncel Tuzel}}</ref>
Transportation/tech website ''[[Jalopnik]]'' reported in late November that Apple was recruiting automotive test engineering and tech talent for autonomous systems work, and appeared to be surreptitiously leasing, via third parties, a former Fiat Chrysler proving grounds site in Surprise, Arizona (originally Wittman).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Felton|first1=Ryan|title=Apple Might Be Leasing Chrysler's Old Proving Grounds To Test Autonomous Car Technology|url=https://jalopnik.com/apple-might-be-leasing-chryslers-old-proving-grounds-to-1820782763|website=Jalopnik|accessdate=29 November 2017}}</ref> Also in 2017, the ''New York Times'' suggested that Apple had stopped developing its own self-driving car.<ref name=J/> In response to such reports, Apple CEO Tim Cook acknowledged publicly that year that the company was working on autonomous-car technology.<ref name=D/>
===2018=== In January 2018, the company registered 27 self-driving vehicles with California's Department of Motor Vehicles.<ref name=D/>
In May 2018, a ''[[New York Times]]'' article reported on major project news.<ref name="NYT May 2018 VW partnership">{{cite web|last1=Nicas|first1=Jack|title=Apple, Spurned by Others, Signs Deal With Volkswagen for Driverless Cars|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/23/technology/apple-bmw-mercedes-volkswagen-driverless-cars.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=24 May 2018|date=23 May 2018}}</ref> After proposed partnership arrangements with Germany's high-end brands [[BMW]] and [[Mercedes-Benz]] failed,<ref name="NYT May 2018 VW partnership"/> as did potential alliances with [[Nissan]], [[BYD Auto]], [[McLaren Automotive]], and others, Apple reportedly partnered with [[Volkswagen]] to produce an autonomous employee shuttle van based on the [[Volkswagen Transporter (T6)|T6 Transporter]] commercial vehicle platform.<ref name="NYT May 2018 VW partnership"/> The T6 Transports would be transformed into autonomous electric versions at VW's [[Italdesign]] subsidiary in [[Turin, Italy]], with the frame, wheels, and chassis remaining the same.<ref name="NYT May 2018 VW partnership"/>
While Apple does its best to keep its autonomous vehicles plans secret,<ref name=A/><ref name=B/> regulatory filings do provide some factual insight into its activities. In September 2018, Apple was reportedly in third place in the number of California autonomous vehicle permits with 70, behind [[GM Cruze]] (175) and [[Alphabet (company)|Alphabet]]'s [[Waymo]] (88).<ref name=B>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/09/11/apple-autonomous-vehicle-test-fleet-california-70/|title=Apple’s autonomous vehicle fleet swells 27% in four months|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-09-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
On July 7, 2018, a former Apple employee was arrested by the [[FBI]] for allegedly stealing trade secrets about Apple's self-driving car project.<ref name=D/><ref name=A>{{cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/fa18f5b4-847e-11e8-a29d-73e3d454535d |title=Apple self-driving car secrets allegedly stolen |author=Kadhim Shubber and Tim Bradshaw |date=July 10, 2018 |publisher=[[The Financial Times]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref> He was charged by federal prosecutors.<ref name=G>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-44793244 |title=Apple employee 'stole driverless car secrets' |author= |date=July 11, 2018 |publisher=[[BBC]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name=D>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/story/ex-apple-employee-accused-of-stealing-self-driving-car-tech/ |title=Ex-Apple Employee Accused of Stealing Self-Driving-Car Tech |author= Klint Finley|date=July 10, 2018 |publisher=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref> The criminal complaint against the former employee revealed that at that time,<ref name=>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidsilver/2018/07/18/for-self-driving-companies-like-apple-stealth-and-learning-are-often-in-tension/#25c3bb1333c4 |title=Apple And Zoox Show How Stealth And Learning Are In Tension On Self-Driving Cars |author=David Silver |date=July 18, 2018 |publisher=[[Forbes]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref> Apple still had yet to openly discuss any of its self-driving research,<ref name=C/> with around 5,000 employees disclosed on the project.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/10/ex-apple-employee-charged-with-stealing-autonomous-car-trade-secrets.html |title=New details about Apple's autonomous driving technology revealed in criminal complaint against ex-engineer |author=Jillian D'Onfro |date=July 10, 2018 |publisher=[[CNBC]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name=E>{{cite web |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/07/11/business/ex-apple-engineer-accused-stealing-driverless-car-secrets-chinese-firm-busted-san-jose-airport/#.W8Un9i2ZNAY |title=Ex-Apple engineer, accused of stealing driverless car secrets for Chinese firm, busted at San Jose airport |author=Bloomberg |date=July 11, 2018 |publisher=[[Japan Times]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name=C>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2018/07/11/ex-apple-engineer-arrested-on-his-way-to-china-charged-with-stealing-companys-autonomous-car-secrets/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.fec5120a2f13 |title=Ex-Apple engineer arrested on his way to China, charged with stealing company’s autonomous car secrets |author=Allyson Chiu |date=July 11, 2018 |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref>
On August 24 2018, it was reported that one of Apple's self-driving car had apparently been involved in a crash, when it was rear-ended during road-testing.<ref name=H/><ref name=K>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/09/01/apple-self-driving-car-crash/ |title=Apple reports its first self-driving car crash |author=Mariella Moon |date=September 1, 2018 |publisher=[[Engadget]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref> The crash occurred while the car was at a stop, waiting to merge into traffic about 3.5 miles from Apple's headquarters in Cupertino, with no reported injuries.<ref name=M>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-45380373 |title=Apple self-driving car in minor crash |author=Dave Lee |date=September 1, 2018 |publisher=[[BBC]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref><ref name=L>{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-self-driving-car-crash-2018-8 |title=One of Apple’s secretive self-driving cars got in a crash for the first time — but it doesn't seem to be Apple's fault |author=Becky Peterson |date=August 31, 2018 |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |access-date=October 15, 2018}}</ref> At the time, the BBC reported that Apple had 66 road-registered driverless cars, with 111 drivers registered to operate those cars.<ref name=H>{{cite web |url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/96212/human-driver-crashes-into-apple-self-driving-car |title=Human driver crashes into Apple self-driving car |author= |date=September 3, 2018 |publisher=[[The Week]] |access-date=}}</ref>
In August 2018, there were reports about an Apple patent that warned riders what moves an autonomous car would make before it made them, purportedly to alleviate nervousness.<ref name=J>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/08/21/apple-self-driving-car-patent-predicts-future-moves.html |title=Apple has an idea for self-driving cars to tell riders what they're about to do so they don't get nervous |author=Todd Haselton |date=August 21, 2018 |publisher=[[CNBC]] |access-date=}}</ref>
== Alleged employees and affiliates ==
* Jamie Carlson, an engineer on Tesla's Autopilot self-driving car program, and before that he worked on automotive vision systems for Michigan-based supplier Gentex Corp.<ref name="reuters-several-hires">{{cite news |title = Tesla Engineer Joins Apple's Growing Team of Automated Car Experts |url = http://ca.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idCAKCN0QQ23420150821?sp=true |first1 = Paul |last1 = Lienert |first2 = Julia |last2 = Love |last-author-amp = yes |date = August 21, 2015 |publisher = Reuters }}</ref> * Megan McClain, a former Volkswagen AG engineer with expertise in automated driving.<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Vinay Palakkode, a graduate researcher at Carnegie Mellon University, a hub of automated driving research.<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Xianqiao Tong, an engineer who developed computer vision software for driver assistance systems at microchip maker Nvidia Corp NVDA.O.<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Paul Furgale, former deputy director of the Autonomous Systems Lab at the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich]].<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Sanjai Massey, an engineer with experience in developing connected and automated vehicles at Ford and several suppliers.<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Stefan Weber, a former Bosch engineer with experience in video-based driver assistance systems.<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Lech Szumilas, a former Delphi research scientist with expertise in computer vision and object detection.<ref name="reuters-several-hires"/> * Doug Betts, former global quality leader at Fiat Chrysler.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://money.cnn.com/2015/07/21/technology/apple-car-chrysler/ |title = Apple Adds a Chrysler Exec to Its Team. Is a Car far Behind? |first = Jose |last = Pagliery |date = July 21, 2015 |publisher = [[CNNMoney]] }}</ref> * Johann Jungwirth, former CEO of Mercedes-Benz Research & Development, North America, Inc.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.tomsguide.com/us/apple-electric-car-new-hire,news-21363.html |title = Apple Electric Car Steers Closer to Reality |first = Michael |last = Andronico |date = July 21, 2015 |work = Tom's Guide }}</ref> – left for VW in Nov. 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.autonews.com/article/20151110/COPY01/311109949/vw-recruits-exec-linked-to-apple-electric-car-project |title = VW Recruits Exec Linked to Apple Electric Car Project |date = November 10, 2015 |work = [[Automotive News]] }}</ref> * Mujeeb Ijaz, a former Ford Motor Co. engineer, who founded [[A123 Systems]]'s Venture Technologies division, which focused on materials research, electrical battery cell product development and advanced concepts (who helped recruited four to five staff researchers from A123, a battery technology company)<ref name="tim-higgins-bloomberg"/> * Nancy Sun, formerly vice president of electrical engineering at electric motorcycle company Mission Motors in San Francisco.<ref name=Reuters-Mission-Motors>{{cite news |last1 = Love |first1 = Julia |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/19/us-apple-motorcycle-idUSKCN0SD0ND20151019 |title = Apple's Auto Ambitions Sideswipe Electric Motorcycle Startup |agency = Reuters |date = October 19, 2015 }}</ref> * Mark Sherwood, formerly director of powertrain systems engineering at Mission Motors.<ref name="Reuters-Mission-Motors"/> * Eyal Cohen, formerly vice president of software and electrical engineering at Mission Motors.<ref name="Reuters-Mission-Motors"/> * Jonathan Cohen, former director of [[Nvidia]]'s [[deep learning]] software.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bergen |first1=Mark |title=Apple Hires an Artificial Intelligence Expert from Nvidia. Is He Going to Work on Self-Driving Cars? |url=http://recode.net/2015/10/23/apple-hires-an-artificial-intelligence-expert-from-nvidia-is-he-going-to-work-on-self-driving-cars/ |website=Re/code |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151024185142/http://recode.net/2015/10/23/apple-hires-an-artificial-intelligence-expert-from-nvidia-is-he-going-to-work-on-self-driving-cars/ |archivedate=October 24, 2015 }}</ref> Nvidia uses deep learning in its Nvidia Drive PX platform, which is used in driver assistance systems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/self-driving-cars/drive-platform/|title=Autonomous Car Development Platform from NVIDIA DRIVE PX2|website=NVIDIA|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> * Chris Porritt – former Tesla vice president of vehicle engineering and former [[Aston Martin]] chief engineer.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-36126591 |title = Ford: 'We Assume Apple Is Working on a Car' |author = |date = |publisher = BBC News |access-date = May 28, 2016 }}</ref> * [[Alex Hitzinger]] is a [[Germany|German]] [[engineer]] who until 31st of March 2016 was the Technical Director of the [[Porsche in motorsport|Porsche]] [[LMP1]] project.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ferdinandmagazine.com/porsche-lmp1-director-hitzinger-quits|title=Porsche LMP1 Technical Director Hitzinger Quits - Ferdinand|date=2016-03-15|newspaper=Ferdinand Porsche Magazine|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-01}}</ref> He previously worked as Head of Advanced Technologies for the [[Red Bull Racing|Red Bull]] and [[Scuderia Toro Rosso|Toro Rosso]] Formula One teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seekingalpha.com/article/4031031-apple-evidence-mounts-full-self-driving-car|title=Apple: Evidence Mounts For A Full Self-Driving Car|author=Mark Hibben|date=December 16, 2016|website=[[Seeking Alpha]]}}</ref>
== See also == {{portal|Apple|Cars}} * [[CarPlay]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}} {{Apple}}
