revision.comment: added [[Category:Natural gas fields in the Soviet Union]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox oil field | name = Arkhangelske | country = {{In Crimea}} | region = [[Black Sea]] | location = | block = | offonshore = offshore | coordinates = | operator = | operators = | partners = [[Chornomornaftogaz]]
[[Shelton Canada]] | contractors = | image = | caption = | discovery = 1989 | start_development = 1990 | start_production = 1991 | abandonment = | peak_year = | peak_of_production_oil_bbl/d = | peak_of_production_oil_tpy = | peak_of_production_gas_mmcuft/d = | peak_of_production_gas_mmscm/d = | peak_of_production_gas_bcm/y = | oil_production_bbl/d = | oil_production_tpy = | production_year_oil = | production_gas_mmcuft/d = 70 | production_gas_mmscm/d = 2 | production_gas_bcm/y = 0.72 | production_year_gas = | est_oil_bbl = | est_oil_t = | recover_oil_bbl = | recover_oil_t = | est_gas_bft = 750 | est_gas_bcm = 18.4 | recover_gas_bft = | recover_gas_bcm = | formations = }} The '''Arkhangelske gas field''' [[natural gas field]] is located in the north-western part of the continental shelf of the [[Black Sea]]. It was discovered in 1989 and developed by [[Chornomornaftogaz]] and [[Shelton Canada]]. It is located {{convert|60|-|70|km}} off the coast, at a depth of {{convert|51|m}}. {{cite news | url = http://ua-energy.org/en/post/21892 | title = Chornomornaftogaz launches new gas well on Arkhangelske field | work = Ukrainian Energy | agency = [[Ukrinform]] | date = 2012-08-21 | accessdate = 2014-03-16}} Arkhangelske field began production in 1991 and produces [[natural gas]] and [[Natural gas condensate|condensates]]. The total [[proven reserves]] of the Arkhangelsk gas field are around {{convert|750|e9cuft}}, and production is slated to be around {{convert|70|e6cuft/d}} in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.gasandoil.com/news/2009/03/cnr90920|title=Shelton acquires Ukraine gas field|date=2009|publisher=gasandoil.com|accessdate=2013-05-12}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Resources in Ukraine}} {{Black Sea Energy}} {{coord missing|Ukraine}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arkhangelsk Gas Field}} [[Category:Natural gas fields in Ukraine]] [[Category:Black Sea energy]] [[Category:Economy of Crimea]] [[Category:Natural gas fields in the Soviet Union]] {{gasfield-stub}} {{Ukraine-geo-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Canadianpetroleumhistory}} Although there are numerous oil companies operating in Canada, the majority of production, refining and marketing is done by fewer than 20 of them.{{cite web|url=http://nrcan.gc.ca/eneene/sources/infinf/refraf-eng.php|title=Natural Resources Canada:Canadian Refineries|date=2009-01-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110216074850/http://www.nrcan.gc.ca/eneene/sources/infinf/refraf-eng.php|archivedate=2011-02-16|df=}} According to the 2013 edition of Forbes Global 2000,{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/global2000/list/#p_1_s_a0_Oil%20&%20Gas%20Operations_All%20countries_All%20states_|title=the global 2000 forbes |date=2012-04-18 |work=forbes.com}} canoils.com{{cite web|url=http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/calgarybusiness/story.html?id=69b0a92f-8f7f-42a1-963a-878897b0af02|title=Suncor ousts Encana as Calgary's market cap leader|accessdate=2010-04-28|date=2010-05-29|work=Calgary Herald|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829200821/http://www2.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/calgarybusiness/story.html?id=69b0a92f-8f7f-42a1-963a-878897b0af02#|archive-date=2012-08-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} and any other list that emphasizes market capitalization and revenue when sizing up companies, as of March 31, 2014 these are the largest Canada-based oil and gas companies (they are either based entirely in Canada or majority Canadian owned). However more recent changes, possibly mergers or a stronger showing in the price of oil could mean a few of the oil sands producers are underrepresented; this is because Canadian companies are increasingly dependent on production from that source, which is hurt severely when oil prices decline below 50 to 60 dollars a barrel since costs per barrel traditionally exceed $28 and non-upgraded bitumen (<10o API) produces 1.7 fewer barrels per metric ton than West Texas Intermediate oil (according to [[API gravity#Using API gravity to calculate barrels of crude oil per metric ton|calculation]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.rigzone.com/news/article.asp?a_id=17850|title=Solid Economics for Oil Sands|date=2004-11-08}} A few of the larger companies ([[Penn West Petroleum]] and [[Athabasca Oil Corporation]]) don't show up in the [[Forbes 2000|Forbes]] list because its ranking system takes many different factors into account. Syncrude and Irving Oil are also leaders in the Canadian industry, with Syncrude being the top producer of oil sands crude and Irving Oil operating the [[Irving Oil Refinery|largest oil refinery]] in the country.{{cite web |url=http://www.indeed.com/cmp/Irving-Oil|title=Irving Oil Company Information|accessdate=2009-08-11 |date=2009-08-06 |work=indeed}} Also, based on the price paid for a 9% share in Syncrude Canada Ltd by [[Sinopec]] the company could be worth as much as US$50 billion.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/investment-ideas/streetwise/sinopec-pays-a-hefty-sum-for-syncrude/article1531659/|title=Sinopec pays a hefty sum for Syncrude| location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail|first=Andrew|last=Willis|date=2010-04-12}} Canadian oil company profits quickly recovered from the financial crisis; In 2009 they were down 90% but in 2010 they reached $8.4 billion; Helping profits is the smaller price gap between West Texas Intermediate oil ($85/bbl) and Western Canadian heavy crude ($65/bbl) with the price of upgraded synthetic oil surpassing WTI when supply falls (before being upgraded to [[synthetic crude]], heavier oil produces fewer barrels of oil per metric ton than lighter oil).{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/17/us-enbridge-gateway-idUSTRE71G4IF20110217|title=Analysis, Foes fight Canada pipeline to rich Asian market|date=2011-02-17 | work=Reuters}}{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/business/breakingnews/better-times-ahead-for-canadas-oil-companies-with-expected-84b-profit-in-2010-102058233.html|title=Better times ahead for Canada's oil companies with expected $8.4B profit in 2010|date=2010-09-02}} The two largest (Suncor and CNRL) are 2 of the 11 most valuable Canadian companies (April 2013).{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/global2000/#page:2_sort:0_direction:asc_search:_filter:All%20industries_filter:Canada_filter:All%20states|title=Forbes Global 2000 Canada|date=April 2013}} 2,412 oil and gas companies are based in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]] alone. {{cite web|url=http://www.financialpost.com/Energy+sector+keen+merger/4492680/story.html|title=Energy sector not so keen on TSX merger|date=2011-03-23}} Ongoing research and development involving extraction technology and processing methods are chipping away at many of the barriers to [[Synthetic crude|bitumen production]]. A number of Canadian oil companies have a lot of exposure to heavy oil through assets in Alberta, they stand to benefit when research into more efficient and cost effective solutions yields positive results (Petrobank has numerous patents related to [[Petrobank Energy and Resources#THAI technology|extraction technology]] that at least one major engineering firm considers 17% more efficient than the widely used [[steam assisted gravity drainage]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.ntm.nickles.com/issues/story.aspx?aid=1000363947|title=Petrobank's THAI Technology Expands Exploitable Bitumen In Place|date=2010-03-12}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In the summer of 2010 a research team at [[Hokkaido University]] discovered a [[catalyst]] that significantly improves the efficiency while lowering costs related to the processing of bitumen.{{cite web|url=http://www.heavyoilinfo.com/news-1/new-technology-for-bitumen-extraction|title=New technology for bitumen extraction|date=2010-08-09|access-date=2010-12-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711161858/http://www.heavyoilinfo.com/news-1/new-technology-for-bitumen-extraction#|archive-date=2011-07-11|dead-url=yes|df=}} Major oil producers are showing renewed interest in new technologies, a direct result of both heightened interest in raising the proportion of the oil sands that can be recovered (10%, which means {{convert|1.6|Toilbbl|km3}} are at stake) and the growing value of licensing rights. That has resulted in a shift in focus over to patent producing research and development. Cenovus Energy has used its patents as a tool to negotiate deals.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/generic/generated/static/business/article1862279.html|title=Petroleum patent pending|date=2011-01-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114213025/http://www.ctv.ca/generic/generated/static/business/article1862279.html|archivedate=2011-01-14|df=}} Profiled and ranked is every Canadian oil and gas company with a [[market capitalization|market cap]] ranking top 500 worldwide and the eight largest by revenue (Nexen made Forbes list but not the top 500 companies according to market capitalization but it had the highest revenue among all other petroleum companies [https://web.archive.org/web/20100730060411/http://list.canadianbusiness.com/rankings/investor500/2009/q1/large-cap/performance/Default.aspx?sc1=2&d1=d&sp2=1&eh=ch according to this list], addax petroleum became part of Sinopec). Eight of the ten most profitable companies of the oil and gas sector operating in Canada are represented here (other two were Athabasca Oil Sands Corp and Heritage Oil).{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/rob-magazine/top-1000/2011-rankings-of-canadas-top-1000-public-companies-by-profit/article2071184/|title=2011 ranking of Canada's top 1000 companies by profit|publisher=globe and mail|date=2011-09-26|location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail}} In 2011 Canadian Natural Resources overtook Suncor to become Canada's largest producer. Suncor produced 549,000 boe/d in 2012 only slightly higher than in 2011. Canadian Natural Resources produced at a gross rate of 655,000 boe/d up from 600,000 boe/d the year before. ==Market capitalization (March 31, 2014), revenue (2016), profit (2016), production, reserves== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! company never to make the global 500 list, according to Forbes [https://www.forbes.com/global2000/#page:1_sort:0_direction:asc_search:_filter:All%20industries_filter:Canada_filter:All%20states] *Encana, Talisman Energy last made the Fortune 500 list in June 2011; Cenovus Energy dropped out December 2013. *CNRL 2013 annual production was estimated to be {{convert|671162|oilbbl|m3|abbr=on}} equivalent/d based on indicated production levels of {{convert|192922|oilbbl|m3|abbr=on}} equivalent ngas (based on conversion factor of 5658.53 cubic feet::1 boe) and {{convert|478240|oilbbl/d|abbr=on}} of oil. *proved reserves (doesn't include most bitumen/heaviest oil in reserves, in some cases probable reserves are included) **proved and probable reserves include those oil and possibly bitumen reserves estimated to be as much if not more than likely recoverable under most recent conditions, production of which is unrestrained by contingencies,{{cite web|url=http://ca.news.finance.yahoo.com/s/16062010/34/biz-f-business-wire-cenovus-total-bitumen-initially-place-estimated-137-billion.html|title=Cenovus total bitumen initially-in-place estimated at 137 billion barrels; 56 billion barrels discovered bitumen initially-in-place Oilsands production|date=2010-06-16}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} for instance, under ideal conditions (the right bitumen extraction technology and oil price) Cenovus's reserves could be as high as {{convert|137|Goilbbl|m3}},{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/cenovus-posts-172-million-profit/article1655846/|title=Cenovus posts $172-million profit |date=2010-09-20 | location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail}}{{cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/tag/cenovus/|title=Cenovus Upgraded on aggressive new Growth Estimates|date=2010-07-15}} 114 times larger than those presently recognized. *After spinning off Cenovus Energy, Encana's production was 95% natural gas. *based on conversion factor of .00018225 from cubic feet of natural gas to barrels of oil equivalent (1/5487).{{cite web|url=http://redstarcanada.com/CONVERSIONS.htm|title=Oil Industry Conversions|accessdate=2010-06-27|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110618142532/http://redstarcanada.com/CONVERSIONS.htm|archivedate=2011-06-18|df=}} ===Suncor Energy=== {{main|Suncor Energy}} [[Image:Petro Canada West Tower.jpg|thumb|left|75px|suncor energy center]] Revenue 36.82 bn MV 59.927 bn (2011) *Suncor Energy completed merger with Canada's 11th largest company Petro Canada on August 1, 2009 in a 21 billion dollar deal to form the largest oil and second largest company overall in Canada.{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2009/08/03/daily65.html|title=suncor, petro canada complete merger|accessdate=2009-08-11 |date=2009-08-06 |work=bizjournals}}{{cite web |url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/fpmagazinedaily/archive/2009/03/23/a-united-petro-canada-and-suncor-canada-s-second-biggest-company.aspx |title=suncor, a united petro canada and suncor Canada's second biggest company ? |accessdate=2009-08-11 |date=2009-07-23 |work=the globe and mail }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At the time of the merger it had a market capitalization of $43 billion and held the biggest position in Alberta's oil sands.{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/suncor-petro-canada-deal-a-go-but-must-sell-104-ontario-gas-stations/article1226711|title=Suncor Petro Canada Deal a go,|accessdate=2009-08-12 |date=2009-08-06 |work=globe and mail |location=Toronto}} *{{convert|680000|oilbbl/d}} of oil production (532,000 from oil sands and conventional oil in 2008).{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2009/03/23/suncor-petro-canada-merge.html |title=suncor, petro Canada merge |accessdate=2009-08-11 |date=2009-03-23 |work=cbc |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326040219/http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2009/03/23/suncor-petro-canada-merge.html |archivedate=March 26, 2009 }} *with about $30 billion in revenue, $50 billion market capitalization and immense growth coming from the oil sands as a result of rising oil prices, the new company should rival the 12th and 13th largest oil and gas companies in the world Rusneft and Lukoil. *After acquiring Petro Canada, Suncor divested at least $2.8 billion worth of Petro Canada assets.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2010/08/12/suncor-asset-sale.html |title=Suncor Asset Sales Worth $375 million |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2010-08-12 |accessdate=2010-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816130342/http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2010/08/12/suncor-asset-sale.html |archivedate=August 16, 2010 }} *In November 2010 Suncor was Canada's 4th most valuable company.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/energy-and-resources/oil-sands-giants-post-big-profits/article1785172/|title=Oil sands giants post big profits|date=2010-11-05 | location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail|first=David|last=Ebner}} *Recently has shown renewed interest in developing patents (including ones for conveyor belts and hand railings), when considered with nine other oil companies patent applications were up 250% between 2005 and 2010 when compared to 2000 to 2004. *In December 2011 oil sands production was at a record high 346,000 bbls/d.{{cite web|url=http://www.suncor.com/pdf/Suncor_Energy_Fourth_Quarter_2011_Results_EN.pdf|title=Suncor 2011 fiscal report|date=January 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227143816/http://www.suncor.com/pdf/Suncor_Energy_Fourth_Quarter_2011_Results_EN.pdf|archivedate=February 27, 2012|df=}} *Total production steady in 2012 at 549 mboe/d. 2011 production fell 11.2% to 546 mboe/d due to the loss of output from Libya. In 2008 production was 680 mboe/d.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE52M1J720090323|title=suncor to buy petro-Canada|work=Reuters|date=2009-03-23}} ===Canadian Natural Resources Limited=== {{main|Canadian Natural Resources}} Revenue 14.625 bn, MV 48.379 bn (2011) *34th ranked oil company in 2009 according to fortune 500, 251 overall.,{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2009/18/global-09_The-Global-2000_IndName_15.html|title=theglobal2000|work=forbes | date=2009-04-08}} 7th most valuable Canadian company in November 2010. *2nd largest natural gas producer in Canada.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=aN6SoOXEyobA|title=Canadian Natural Reports Profit on Alberta Oil Sands|accessdate=2009-08-11 |date=2009-08-06 |work=bloomberg}} *During the third quarter of 2010 upstream oil and natural gas production reached the highest rate among Canadian producers (the rate was not maintained however, production fell back slightly due to planned and unplanned maintenance shutdowns).{{cite web|author=Grmike |url=http://www.wikinvest.com/wiki/Canadian_natural_resources |title=Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ) |publisher=Wikinvest.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-24}} *operates in the [[North Sea]] (4% of oil production), [[Western Canada]] (93% of oil / 97% of gas production), and [[West Africa]] (3% of oil / 2% of gas production). *In last quarter of 2011 company production leaped by a significant margin and stayed there: 2011 production: 657,599 b/d in the fourth quarter, 598,526 b/d over the entire year.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnrl.com/upload/media_element/470/03/0308_q4-11.pdf|title=Canadian Natural Resources 2011 4th quarter report|year=2012}} Gross output went on to average 655th b/d in 2012, 671th b/d in 2013. *oil accounts for 90% of product sales (2013). ===Encana Corporation=== {{main|Encana}} [[File:Bow-june10.JPG|thumb|100px|right|Encana HQ u.constr will be the tallest in [[Western Canada|W.Canada]]{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&id=282150&lng=3|title=Emporis The Bow|accessdate=2010}}]] Revenue 9.097 bn MV 21.419 bn (2011) Encana, North America's largest natural gas producer was formed in 2002 when PanCanadian Energy merged with Alberta Energy Company.{{cite web |url=https://windsorstar.com/business/EnCana+profit+rises+three+fold/2936138/story.html|title=Encana Profit Rises 3 Fold| date=2010-04-22 |work=reuters}}{{cite web|url=http://www.metronews.ca/ottawa/business/article/508081--encana-predicts-low-natural-gas-prices-for-2010-books-big-q1-gains-on-hedging--page2|title=Encana Predicts Low Natural Gas Prices in 2010|date=2010-04-22|work=The Canadian Press}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://stocks.investopedia.com/stock-analysis/2009/Top-5-Natural-Gas-Producers-XTO-BP-APC-CHK-DVN-XOM1016.aspx|title=Top 5 Natural Gas Producers in the USA|date=2009-10-16|work=Investopedia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419071634/http://stocks.investopedia.com/stock-analysis/2009/Top-5-Natural-Gas-Producers-XTO-BP-APC-CHK-DVN-XOM1016.aspx|archivedate=2010-04-19|df=}} It operates in Alberta, British Columbia, Nova Scotia, Colorado, Wyoming, Texas and Louisiana and had the largest reserve base among Canadian producers as recently as 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.petrostrategies.org/Links/worlds_largest_oil_and_gas_companies.htm|title=encana|accessdate=2009-08-11 |date=2009-04-08 |work=petrostrategies}} At the end of 2009 Encana created Cenovus Energy when it split its integrated oil and natural gas components.{{cite web|url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/tradingdesk/archive/2009/11/02/new-encana-and-cenovus-start-trading-today.aspx|title=New Encana and Cenovus start trading today|date=2009-11-02|work=National Post}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In February 2012 Encana sold 40% of its 100% interest in the Cutbank Ridge Complex, a natural gas resource in NE British Columbia.{{cite web|url=http://www.lngworldnews.com/canada-encana-completes-cutbank-ridge-deal-with-mitsubishi/|title=Encana Completes Cutbank Ridge Deal with Mitsubishi|date=2012-02-27}} The deal is worth $2.9 billion, in 2011 the company made $3.5 billion in deals. The deal came just after another one involving Petro China collapsed. *Headquarters: The {{convert|774|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall skyscraper called [[The Bow (skyscraper)|The Bow]] is the tallest office building in Calgary and the tallest built in Canada since 1990. ===Husky Energy=== {{main|Husky Energy}} [[Image:Husky Gas Station Edmonton Alberta 3831.jpg|left|thumb|130px|Husky gas station located in Edmonton, Alberta]] Revenue 18.261 bn MV 23.648 bn (2011) [[Husky Energy]] was founded in Wyoming by Albertan Glenn Nielson who with 2 partners, bought 2 heavy oil refineries, and used them to establish the Husky Refining Co. in 1938. This was followed by major purchases of oil rich land and gas stations. In 1946 Nielson moved part of the company to Canada where Husky Oil Ltd. was created separate from the parent company. By the late 1970s the company's need for more funding eventually forced Nielson to sell all his stake in the company. Another Albertan, Bob Blair CEO of the pipeline company AGTL (later renamed Nova Corp.) took advantage of the situation gradually increasing his stake in the company until he owned a controlling interest. About a decade later Husky ran into financial problems that were solved when Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing started investing in the company leading to a buy out of Blair's interests in 1991. The 1988 acquisition of Centerra Energy Ltd. made Husky a top 10 Canadian oil company. After a turbulent couple decades, Husky reasserted itself as a major Canadian petroleum company in 2000 by purchasing Renaissance Energy Ltd. in a [[Canadian dollar|$]]3.02 billion deal. Husky Energy has proven petroleum reserves of {{convert|430000000|oilbbl}} and {{convert|2|e12cuft|m3}} of natural gas. It owns approximately 500 filling stations in Canada as well as property and/or mineral rights to some 6.67 million acres (27,000 km²) in Western Canada.{{cite web|url=http://companies.jrank.org/pages/2087/Husky-Energy-Inc.html |title=Husky Energy Inc. Business Information, Profile, and History - Oil, Company, Canada, Gas, Ltd, and Alberta |publisher=Companies.jrank.org |date=1938-01-01 |accessdate=2010-12-24}} Husky's oil production was exactly the same in 2011 as it was in 2003 (312,500 boe/d).{{cite web|url=http://www.fr-communiquedepresse.net/jj/Husky+Energy+augmente+le+b%C3%A9n%C3%A9fice+net+de+135+en+2011+lorsque+la_caacdd.htm|title=Husky Energy augmente le bénéfice net de 135% en 2011 lorsque la production augmentera de 9%|date=2012-02-10}} ===Enbridge=== Revenue 15.539 bn MV 21.664 bn (2011) {{main|Enbridge}} [[File:EnbridgeBuildingEdmonton.jpg|thumb|right|80px|Enbridge building in Edmonton, Alberta]] Began as a pipeline company called interprovincial pipelines incorporated by Imperial Oil in the 1940s as a result of growth at the Leduc oil fields in Alberta exceeding the capacity of Alberta's refineries to process the oil. In 1950 its pipelines were operational and in 1953 it was a publicly traded company at stock exchanges in Toronto and Montreal. By the late 1950s its main pipeline was almost {{convert|2000|mi|km}} long handling about {{convert|200000|oilbbl}} of oil per day in certain sections. In the late 1960s refineries in the US and Canada demanded more oil be delivered from Canadian sources, and the solution deemed best by management, and government officials was to build a new line through Chicago. The access expansion gave the company to Chicago helped the company grow rapidly and by the early 1970s throughput reached {{convert|900000|oilbbl}} of oil. By 1986 Imperial Oil's ownership of the company was down to 33% and through an exchange of shares Imperial Oil helped interprovincial acquire another oil company called Hiram Walker while subsequently changing its name to Interhome Energy Inc. Later it was renamed IPL Energy Inc. During the 1990s it acquired a number of other companies (consumers gas, altagas, interest in Chicap pipeline) which delivered natural gas as well but most of the company's business was still in crude oil. The new divisions gave the company greater access to Toronto, Quebec and New York. Its last name change made in 1998 was to Enbridge Inc. a combination of the words energy and bridge.{{cite web|url=http://companies.jrank.org/pages/1425/Enbridge-Inc.html|title=Enbridge|publisher=jrank|accessdate=2010-07-01}} Currently Enbridge owns the world's longest oil pipeline system (delivers {{convert|2000000|oilbbl}} per day), owns Canada's largest natural gas distributing company, and has 1.9 million customers. It is also active in the alternative energy sector, having an interest in wind farms, [[waste heat recovery unit|waste heat recovery]] plants and photovoltaic projects the largest of which is the Sarnia Solar Project.{{cite web |url=http://www.crocodyl.org/wiki/enbridge_inc|title=Enbridge Inc.|publisher=Crocodyl|accessdate=2010-10-16}}{{cite web|url=http://investor.firstsolar.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=201491&p=irol-newsArticle&id=1478697|title=Enbridge and First Solar Complete the Largest Photovoltaic Facility in the World|date=2010-10-04}} Revenue comes from commodity sales (79%), gas distribution sales (6.9%), transportation and other services (14.0%). ===Cenovus Energy=== {{main|Cenovus Energy}} Revenue 13.621 bn MV 25.049 bn (2011) Cenovus Energy Inc. is the former component of [[Encana]] that focused more on integrated oil than natural gas though natural gas continues to contribute about half of total production (exceeded oil (crude and synthetic combined) as recently as the end of 2009 however a steady fall in output combined with new oil sands production has reduced that). Cenovus Energy owns a 50% interest in two major US refineries operated by [[Phillips 66|Phillips_66]], which can act as a natural hedge for the company as commodity prices fluctuate. ===Talisman Energy=== {{main|Talisman Energy}} In 2011 and 2012 Talisman sold off some of its largest assets including 50% of British operations; that resulted in revenue loss ($8.347b in 2011 to $7.312b in 2012). Originally BP Canada, Talisman Energy is a publicly traded [[Tsx 60]] [[petroleum]] company that operates in Canada, USA, Columbia, Scotland, Peru, Algeria, Tunisia, UK, Norway, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, Australia, and Qatar. *{{convert|420000|oilbbl}} of oil per day production.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601082&sid=a3cr.elvz2iE&refer=canada|title=Talisman Energy Net Income Rises 83% on Derivatives |accessdate=2009-08-11|date=2009-03-05 |work=cbc}} ===Nexen=== {{main|Nexen}} [[Image:Nexen Building.JPG|left|thumb|120 px]] Revenue 5.840 bn MV 11.986 bn (2011) In February 2013 Nexen was taken over by Cnooc in a $15.1 billion deal.{{cite web|url=http://www2.macleans.ca/2013/02/27/cnooc-in-no-hurry-to-ink-more-oilpatch-deals-after-nexen-takeover-closes/|title=Cnooc in no hurry to ink more oilpatch deals after Nexen takeover closes|date=February 27, 2013}} At the time, Nexen's 2.5 billion boe reserves would've ranked 8th among Canada's oil companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.northamericaninterests.ca/canadian-oil-producers.php#Reserves|title=Canadian oil companies ranked by reserves|accessdate=July 1, 2013}} When Nexen was created in 1971 it was a subsidiary of the American company [[Occidental Petroleum]] called Canadian Occidental Petroleum. After taking over a number of smaller companies in Canada while increasing their international holdings they became larger and more independent of their parent company that by then held only a minor stake. In 2001 the name was changed to nexen in recognition of that. In 2012 the company profited $333 million on revenues of $6.7 billion which is down since 2008 (US $8–9 billion, market value of US $11.14 billion, and a profit of US $1.68 billion).{{cite web|url=http://www.rakedin.com/company/nexen|title=nexen company profile|accessdate=2009-08-24|date=2009-04-08|work=rakedin}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On November 29, 2011 Nexen sold 40% of its Horn River, Cordova and Liard basins shale-gas assets in northeast B.C. to Inpex Corp and JGC Corp of Japanese for US$676 million.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20111129-706066.html|title=Nexen Sells 40% Stake In B.C. Shale-Gas Assets To Japanese Group|date=November 29, 2011 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} At the [[Long Lake (oil sands)|Long Lake project]] oil is upgraded by a process known as [[steam assisted gravity drainage]]. Operates in Canada, Yemen, Colombia, West Africa and the UK (offshore). *Market cap peaked in 2008 at between US$20 and 24 billion (at the time it was reported that oil major [[Total S.A.|Total]] was prepared to offer US$19.7 billion for the company){{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/investment-ideas/streetwise/article724764.ece|title=Nexen takeover rumours pick up steam |date=2008-12-02 | location=Toronto|work=The Globe and Mail}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} but has since fluctuated between $US10 and $US14 billion{{cite web |url=http://www.getmoneyenergy.com/2009/11/large-cap-canadian-energy-materials-stocks/ |title=Large-Cap Canadian Energy and Materials Stocks ''Nov 2009'' |publisher=Getmoneyenergy.com |date=2009-11-19 |accessdate=2010-12-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101217121039/http://www.getmoneyenergy.com/2009/11/large-cap-canadian-energy-materials-stocks/ |archivedate=2010-12-17 |df= }} In February 2011 the Usan offshore oil field began producing. It has a capacity of 180,000 barrels per day and Nexen holds a 20% interest in it.{{cite web|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/nexen-says-first-oil-produced-offshore-field-near-145513120.html|title=Nexen says first oil produced at its offshore field near West Africa|date=2012-02-24}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *production : {{convert|207000|oilbbl}} of oil/day in 2011 16% lower than the year before. Production net of royalties was 186,000 boe/d.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymarkets.com/stock/2012/02/17/nexen-beats-earnings-rev-est/|title=Nexen|date=2012-02-17}} ===Syncrude=== {{main|Syncrude}} *Based on the price paid for a 9% share by [[Sinopec]] the company could be worth as much as $US50 billion. *Syncrude is the world's largest producer of oil sands crude. *Opened in 1978 and started expanding in 1996 *is a joint venture involving 4 Canadian companies (80.97% owned), 3 American(19.93% owned), and 1 Japanese.{{cite web|url=http://www.syncrude.ca/users/news_view.asp?FolderID=5690&NewsID=95|title=Syncrude Joint Venture owners approve Management Services Agreement between Syncrude and Imperial|accessdate=2009-08-11|date=2006-11-01|work=Syncrude Canada Limited|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706205610/http://www.syncrude.ca/users/news_view.asp?FolderID=5690&NewsID=95|archivedate=2011-07-06|df=}} * #1 single source of oil in Canada{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/syncrude/--ID__107209--/free-co-profile.xhtml|title=Syncrude Corporate Information}} ===Irving Oil=== {{main|Irving Oil}} * operates the largest refinery in Canada and has 1.3 billion dollars in revenue *The family that controls the company includes 3 billionaires Arthur, James, and John E. Irving *Operates 769 gas stations in Atlantic Canada, New England and Quebec as well as the convenience stores at many of those locations and the '''Big Stop''' chain of family restaurants. *The company has been based in New Brunswick since it was established in 1924. ===Addax petroleum=== {{main|Sinopec}} Addax Petroleum (Sinopec) was one of about 60 Canadian companies that made it onto the [[Forbes Global 2000]] 2009 list. It was acquired by sinopec of China in June 2009 for C$8.27 billion. ==Other large oil and gas companies== These companies have at least 2 billion dollars in market value (6 of them being near or over $10 billion, the rest are between four and seven billion with the exception of Petrobank, Sherritt and [[Laricina Energy]]). In order of size *Corporations that were all trusts until 2011 when they converted **[[Canadian Oil Sands]] - 36% interest in Syncrude could be worth as much as $US15 billion, revenue was $3.703 billion in 2012 up from $3.46 billion in 2010, $4.54 billion in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/finance?q=TSE:COS.UN&fstype=ii |title=Google Finance Canadian Oil Sands Trust financials |publisher=Google.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-12-24}} **[[Penn West Petroleum]] - Revenue was $2.64 billion in 2012, down 12% on the year, down 35% since 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/finance?q=TSE:PWT.UN&fstype=ii |title=Google Finance Penn West Energy Trust financials |publisher=Google.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-05-09}} For the first nine months of 2011 51.9% of company production came from light and medium oil up from 47.6% the year before (83,675 bpd out of 161,171 boe/d).{{cite web|url=http://www.pennwest.com/documents/PWT_Q3_Nov10.pdf|title=Penn West Exploration 2011 3rd quarter report|date=November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217164705/http://www.pennwest.com/documents/PWT_Q3_Nov10.pdf|archivedate=2012-02-17|df=}} **[[Crescent Point Energy]] - Oil and gas company with interests in the bakken oil field of Alberta. in July 2010 acquired Shelter Bay Energy ({{convert|38.1|koilbbl|m3|abbr=on}} equivalent of oil reserves) for $1.1 billion.{{cite web|url=http://www.articleshub.org/article/31976/Mergers--Acquisitions-Deal-Analysis--Crescent-Point-Energy-To-Acquire-Shelter-Bay-Energy--new-market-report-published.html|title=Crescent Point Energy To Acquire Shelter Bay Energy|date=2010-12-24}} Its market value climbed from $5.5 billion in August 2009 to $7.7 billion in July 2010 then surpassing $10 billion late that year.{{cite web|url=http://www.crescentpointenergy.com/documents/financials/CPG-2010-Q3.pdf|title=Crescent Point Energy 2010 Third Quarter Report|year=2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708203515/http://www.crescentpointenergy.com/documents/financials/CPG-2010-Q3.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/finance?q=TSE:CPG&fstype=ii |title=Google Finance Crescent Point Energy Trust financials |publisher=Google.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-12-24}}{{cite web|url=http://albertaventure.com/2010/09/largest-market-capitalization-2010/|title=Alberta Venture|date=2010-09-01}} **[[ARC Resources]] - Just over $1.0 billion in revenue in 2012, 2011, and 2010 (up 23% versus 2009, about the same as it was in 2007), in 2009 revenue was at its lowest level in 5 years. **[[Baytex Energy]] - Most of production currently is heavy oil however many of its projects involve light oil. **[[Pengrowth Energy]] - For years between 2009 and 2012 revenue ranged from $1.1 to $1.2 billion, 16% more than what it was in 2006. Production grew 26.58% between 2006 and 2009 reaching {{convert|79518|oilbbl|m3|abbr=on}} equivalent/d (about half from natural gas) though production was highest in 2007 ({{convert|87401|oilbbl|m3|abbr=on}} equivalent/d){{cite web|url=http://www.pengrowth.com/pdfs/AnnualReport2009.pdf|title=Pengrowth Energy Trust 2009 Annual Report '''page 2'''|year=2010}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/finance?q=TSE:PGF.UN&fstype=ii |title=Google Finance Pengrowth Energy Trust financials |publisher=Google.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-12-24}} **[[Enerplus]] - Has operations and projects in four Canadian provinces (Western Canada) and seven U.S. states. Produced about {{convert|79000|oilbbl|m3|abbr=on}} equivalent/d in 2010 60% of which is natural gas. 2012 revenue was $1.19 billion about the same as 2010, half of what it was in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/finance?q=TSE:ERF.UN&fstype=ii |title=Google Finance Enerplus Resources Fund financials |publisher=Google.ca |date= |accessdate=2013-05-09}} **[[Inter Pipeline Fund]] - Oversees one of Canada's biggest petroleum and petrochemical transport, pipeline and storage business; transports most of Canada's [[Oil sands|oil sands bitumen]] produced by such companies as [[Shell Canada]], [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] and [[Encana]]. Major moves include the 2007 $760 million acquisition of the Corridor pipeline in Alberta, 2008 $1.8 billion expansion of oil sands pipelines, 2004 $540 million purchase of 3 of Canada's largest natural gas treatment plants. Market value was $4 billion in 2008 more than 6 times what it was in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.ab-conservation.com/go/tasks/sites/default/assets/File/pdfs/07Media/01InTheNews/Oilsands_Review_May_2008_-_A_Blossoming_Counterbalance.pdf|title=Oilsands Review May 2008 page 19|date=May 2008|access-date=2010-12-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707072644/http://www.ab-conservation.com/go/tasks/sites/default/assets/File/pdfs/07Media/01InTheNews/Oilsands_Review_May_2008_-_A_Blossoming_Counterbalance.pdf#|archive-date=2011-07-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} **[[Keyera]] - [[midstream]] company with 18 natural gas liquid processing plants in Alberta. *Independent Oil and Gas **[[Pacific Rubiales Energy]] - Deeply rooted in Colombia where it enjoys strategic partnerships with [[Ecopetrol]] (state oil company that produces about 63% of all Colombian oil and gas production) and where a major part of the company was started (Petro Rubiales, acquired in 2008 was one of the original developers of the Rubiales Field one of Colombia's largest). It is the 2nd largest independent oil and gas company operating in South America.{{cite web|url=http://www.latinbusinesschronicle.com/app/article.aspx?id=4266|title=Pacific Rubiles:Strong Colombia Growth|date=2010-06-04|publisher=Latin Business Chronicle|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128061246/http://latinbusinesschronicle.com/app/article.aspx?id=4266|archivedate=2010-11-28|df=}} **[[MEG Energy]] - Borderline large cap oil sands producer with {{convert|5|Goilbbl|m3}} {{convert|6|Goilbbl|m3}} of 2P reserves in Christina Lake and Surmont (the 2 projects are 50 km apart). **[[Tourmaline Oil Corp]] - Primarily a natural gas company with operations in Northern BC and central Alberta. In the first half of 2012 88% of daily production was natural gas. Completes Acquisition of Huron Energy Corporation|date=2012-11-30}} **[[Paramount Resources Limited]] - Calgary based producer of oil and natural gas. The company operates in three Canadian provinces and two US states. Natural gas accounts for 80% of total production and 77% of total reserves. **[[Athabasca Oil Sands Corp]] **[[Niko Resources|Niko Resources Ltd]] - Oil and Gas company with significant natural gas reserves in India. It is also one of the largest owners of underwater exploration properties in Indonesia (though it has a history that goes back to 1987 it only recently began producing at significant levels). **[[Vermilion Energy]], [[Pembina Pipeline]], [[Petrominerales]], [[Petrobank Energy and Resources]], [[Sherritt International Corporation]], [[Laricina Energy]] (Private ''in-situ'' oil producer worth $1.2 billion) **[http://www.a2nenergy.com A2N Energy], a company having estimated reserves of 560 million barrels. Currently in startup stage. ==Forbes ranking of Canadian companies== 113 oil and gas companies made the list in 2015 (down from 121 in 2014 / 98 in 2013 / 131 in 2012 / 126 in 2011 / 115 in 2010) 10 of which are Canadian (down from 12 in 2014 / 9 in 2013 / 13 in 2012 / 14 in 2011 / 8 in 2010). Dropping out of the list was Canadian Oil Sands Ltd, Pacific Rubiales Energy in 2015, Penn West Petroleum in 2013, Arc Resources in 2012. {{about|the term used in petroleum geology|the term used in biology|Catagenesis (biology)}}
'''Catagenesis''' is a term used in [[petroleum geology]] to describe the [[cracking (chemistry)|cracking]] process which results in the conversion of organic [[kerogen]]s into [[hydrocarbon]]s.
==Theoretical reaction==
Catagenesis is the second stage of maturation of organic carbon on the path to becoming graphitic. This geologic process accounts for very significant changes in the biogenic materials that make up the carbonaceous sediment. During catagenesis, the temperature increases, the pressure increases, and both organic and inorganic constituents “adjust” their phase or form to compensate. The process of “lithification” begins during this stage. Generally speaking, a rise in temperature results in the volatization of unstable species or elements that are weakly attached to carbon atoms. Increased temperature and pressure also result in the cessation of biogenic processes. One way to express these changes is to look at the ratio of oxygen to carbon, or hydrogen to carbon as the sediment matures. In almost all cases, as biogenic material matures in a geologic environment, the volatile elements such as oxygen and hydrogen are significantly reduced, resulting in a reduction in the O/C and H/C ratios. A typical O/C ratio value for a fully matured, catagenesis stage carbon might be less than 0.1. This means that for every 100 carbon atoms there are less than 10 oxygen atoms. Similar reductions in the level of hydrogen are also apparent.
This [[chemical reaction]] is believed to be a [[time]], [[temperature]] and [[pressure]] dependent process which creates liquid and/or gaseous hydrocarbon Hc from primary kerogen X and can be summarised using the formula:
:<math>X_0 \rightarrow Hc + X(t)</math> where X<sub>0</sub> is the initial kerogen [[concentration]] and X(t) is the kerogen concentration at time t.
It is generally held that the dependence on pressure is negligible, such that the process of catagenesis can be given as a first-order [[differential equation]]:
: <math>\frac{dX}{dt} = - \kappa X</math> where X is the reactant (kerogen) and κ is the [[reaction rate constant]] which introduces the temperature-dependence via the [[Arrhenius equation]].
==Important parameters== Several generally unrecognized but important controlling parameters of metamorphism have been suggested.<ref name="Price1997">{{cite journal | last = Price | first = Leigh C. | title = Minimum Thermal Stability Levels and Controlling Parameters of Methane, As Determined by C<sub>15</sub>+ Hydrocarbon Thermal Stabilities | journal = Geologic controls of deep natural gas resources in the United States (USGS Bulletin 2146) | pages = 139–176 | publisher = USGS |year= 1997 | url = https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/usgspubs/b/b2146 | accessdate = 2006-10-10 }}</ref> * The absence or presence of water in the system, because hydrocarbon-thermal destruction is significantly suppressed in the presence of water. * Increasing fluid pressure strongly suppresses all organic-matter metamorphism. * Product escape from reaction sites, as lack of product escape retards metamorphism. * Increasing temperature as the principal driver of reactions.
==Future Work== A great deal of future research is required to isolate the parameters which are most significant for inducing the Catagenetic process. Future work in the field will involve the following:
* Establishing the precise relationship between burial time and hydrocarbon cracking. * Determining how hydrogen from water is ultimately incorporated in kerogen. * Establishing the effect of regional shearing. * Determining how static fluid pressure affects hydrocarbon generation. Some experiments have demonstrated that static fluid pressure may explain the presence of hydrocarbon concentrations at depths where their composition would not otherwise be expected. * Many measurements of hydrocarbon content in sample rocks have been done at atmospheric pressure. This ignores the loss of large amounts of hydrocarbons during depressurization. Rock samples at atmospheric pressure have been measured at 0.11–2.13 percent of samples at formation pressure. Observations at well sites include fizzing of rock chips and oil films covering [[drilling mud]] pits. * Types of organic matter can not be ignored. Different types of organic matter have different chemical bonds, bond strength patterns, and thus different activation energies. * C<sub>15</sub>+ hydrocarbons are stable at much higher temperatures than predicted by first-order reaction kinetics.* For example, while it was once assumed that catagenetic processes were [[Order of reaction#First order|first-order reaction]]s, some research has shown that this may not be the case.<ref name="Price1997" />
==See also== *[[Diagenesis]] *[[Fossil fuel]]s *[[Metamorphic reaction]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Catagenesis (Geology)}} [[Category:Petroleum geology]] [[Category:Fossil fuels]]

{{Orphan|date=September 2012}} {{thermodynamics|cTopic=Processes and Cycles}} The '''Cheng cycle''' is a retrofit to the [[gas turbine]] cycle. The Cheng cycle involves the heated exhaust gas from the turbine being used to make steam in a heat recovery steam generator (HRSG).<ref>Penning, F. M. and de Lange, F. M. (1995) Steam Injection: analysis of a typical application ''Applied Thermal Engineering'' Vol. 16, No. 2, pp. 115 125</ref> The steam so produced is injected into the gas turbine's combustion chamber to increase power output.<ref>De Paepe, M. and E. Dick (2001) Technological and economical analysis of water recovery in steam injected gas turbines, ''Applied Thermal Engineering'', Volume 21, Issue 2, January 2001, Pages 135–156</ref> The process can be thought of as a parallel combination of the gas turbine [[Brayton cycle]] and a steam turbine [[Rankine cycle]].<ref>Stadler,F. and U. Schneider, (1997) ELIN Cheng Cycle, Elin Energieversorgung GmbH, 1997</ref><ref>Motz,D.A. (1987) The Cheng Cycle: principles and applications, ''Ass. Energy Engng, 8th World Energy Engng Conf., Atlanta, USA</ref> The cycle was invented by Prof. D. Y. Cheng of the [[University of Santa Clara]] who patented it in 1976.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=PKBKP6XWCq4C&pg=PA316&lpg=PA316&dq=%22Cheng+cycle%22&source=bl&ots=G2Y2DpTFzw&sig=g8MmVeuUw5utAe4zWj1-hQ5KTKM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=I5Q7UI9QgavRBerhgNgC&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Cheng%20cycle%22&f=false Cen,Ke-fa Yong Chi, Jianhua Yan (2007) ''Challenges of Power Engineering and Environment: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Engineering'', Springer] (Accessed August 2012)</ref><ref>Cheng, D.Y. and A.L.C. Nelson (2002) ''Chronological development of the cheng cycle steam injected gas turbine during the past 25 years''. in: Anon (Ed.), ''Proceedings of ASME Turbo Expo'' 2002, Amsterdam, ASME Paper No. GT-2002-30119 (2002), pp. 421–428</ref>
==See also== * [[Combined cycle]] * [[Brayton cycle]] * [[Rankine cycle]] * [[Cogeneration]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Power engineering]] [[Category:Thermodynamic cycles]]

'''Chinese wax''' is a white to yellowish-white, gelatinous, [[crystal]]line water-insoluble substance obtained from the [[wax]] secreted by certain insects.
It resembles [[spermaceti]] but is harder, more [[friable]], and with a higher melting point. Two [[scale insects]] produce the wax: ''[[Ceroplastes ceriferus]]'', common in [[China]] and [[India]], and the related ''[[Ericerus pela]]'', found in China and [[Japan]]. These insects deposit their secretions on the branches of certain species of ''Ligustrum'' (privet) tree. The insects and their secretions are harvested and boiled with water to extract the raw wax. The insect bodies, which settle to the bottom, are used as food for [[swine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/112805/Chinese-wax|title=Chinese wax - insect secretion|publisher=}}</ref>
According to an article in a November 1932 magazine article in the journal ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' by Herbert Beardsley, "...the male larvae of a white insect, about the size of a mosquito, built a cocoon of pure, shining wax. The tree that produces the white wax insect grows in the [[Chien-Chang]] Valley, and there, about march, one may see, on the limbs and branches, round, brown forms, which contain innumerable white insects. If they are allowed to remain where they are, they will eventually drop off in a dead mass, for the food is not right for them; but if they are transported to other kinds of plants, the females will lay their eggs, the larvae will thrive and the male larvae will construct their shining palaces, which yield a profit to the wax-farmers. So, late in March, the insects are tied up in a leaf of the wood oil tree, then placed in gourd like receptacles which are packed into two large bamboo baskets. Runners or porters lift the baskets on their shoulders, and, traveling entirely at night – for to submit the insects to the midday heat would cause the pupal stage to end too soon – traverse the rocky paths and lofty ascents of the Cze-Chuan Mountains to arrive finally at the farming districts. The baskets of insects are distributed to the farmers, who proceed at once to place the creatures upon the food plant, which is generally a species of flowering ash about five or six feet high. They are tied to the branches in small bags made of leaves, and holes are punched in the bags with a blunt needle so the adults may find their way out. When first emerging, the insects creep rapidly up to the leaves of the food plant, where they nestle for nearly two weeks. After this they begin to scatter and crawl along the branches. About the first of June, the females begin to lay their eggs, and the wax cocoons are formed in August in time completely coating every branch and stem. By the first of September the whole tree is literally covered with layers of pure white wax a quarter of an inch thick. The farmers then scrape the branches, and prepare the wax of the market."<ref>Herbert Beardsley, Nature Magazine article from November issue 1932</ref>
==Uses== Chinese wax is used chiefly in the manufacture of polishes, sizes, and [[candle]]s. Candles, temple images and other articles connected with ceremonial worship, and polish for furniture. It is also used for burnishing the back of Chinese [[hanging scroll]]s with a stone.
In China the wax has been employed medicinally. Taken internally, it has been used as a remedy for [[hoarseness]], pain, [[Helminths|worm]]s, [[Anxiety|nervousness]], and to aid the mending of broken bones. Externally, it has been used as an [[ointment]] for treatment of [[wound]]s.
==Other names== Other names for Chinese wax include: *Chinese tree wax *Chinese insect wax *Insect wax *White wax
In Japan the tree yielding it is called ''ibota'' and the wax ''ibotaro''. Among other uses, it is used to polish white clamshell [[Go_(game)|go]] stones.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Waxes]] [[Category:Traditional Chinese medicine]]
